author: {'steamid': '76561198040975292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1986, 'last_played': 1511450192}
review:
I never thought a cooking game could be so damn good and challenging!
At first, the game is pretty easy, with simple recipes to help you get used to it, but later on it becomes a typing madness!
The drawings are charming, the music is superb and the gameplay is perfect: it's addicting, not too repetitive and the difficulty can easily be changed thanks to the variety of recipes and the difficulty on each dish.
If you are looking to test your memory and reaction skills, this is the game for you!
But if you are looking for some humour or great art, this is ALSO the game for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025315047', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3484, 'last_played': 1508518383}
review:
Simple premise, beautiful execution, and a lot more meat on its bones than you might expect.
Of course, twitch reflex business micro-management by way of countless variations of hotkey sequences is not going to be of interest to everyone. But if you're tempted, I highly recommend this one.

This frantically fast multi-tasking game is challenging by nature, but manages to avoid being punishing with an excellently modulated difficulty curve and a lot of player control in their own difficulty experience; Things too fast for you? Ditch some of the more time-consuming items on your menu, "practice" any that are giving you trouble until your fingers know where the right keys are almost before you do, and don't optimize your "buzz" as much - then you'll be faced with easier tasks coming at you more slowly, for as long as you want until you're ready to step it back up.

It's delightfully easy to pick back up after not playing for a while. Tutorials and practice tools are available to you whenever you need them. You can even practice cooking a food you haven't even bought yet, to help you decide whether you want to commit to the time and effort it will take.

Beyond the basic structure, the game also incorporates a lot of extra material, including catering events, TV appearances, being robbed, betting on your own skills, holding a romantic text message conversation and funding projects on the game's version of kickstarter; and they are all integrated with impressive fluidity into the existing system.

If you want even more than that, there are weekly time challenges in which you can compete with the whole online community, and apparently there's even a mode in which you can play this game with local multiplayer. I haven't tried it myself, and have no idea how it would work, but it's there.

That said, the game isn't completely perfect. There are so many different foods and hotkeys that it can be hard to remember that onions can be O for one food and N for another. Accidentally hitting 4 instead of 5 (for instance) can mean an immediate bad order as you hand off raw chicken to a customer. For some reason tossing out garbage bags always feels unresponsive in the throw unless you slow down for it.
But these are all minor quibbles, and if you do make one of the many easy mistakes, it's not the end of the world. You'll take a minor hit to your reputation for the next day, and don't get the coveted Perfect Day this time around. No biggie. Maybe you'll manage to achieve perfection in the next round.
After all, nobody claimed this was going to be easy, right?

author: {'steamid': '76561198094642117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1533228534}

review:
BASIC DESCRIPTION. 
CSD can be best described as a mixture of DDR, meets key press event game, meets restaurant/cafe manager. 

The game is simple to learn, but has a high skill curb. A great sense of satisfaction is derived from smashing out combo's, by typing like a mad ****, during morning and evening rushes. 

In a word: addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147977771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1437019665}
review: Im a line cook and this is the closest game to what i do every day. Its fun inventive and adds an element of stress. its also good for light casual gamers to pick up whenever they want.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079995036', 'num_games_owned': 657, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1587, 'last_played': 1519093518}
review: This game is fantastic! When I got it, I saw the reviews claiming that it's a very difficult game. Judging by the screenshots, I thought they were joking. It looked like a pretty casual game. BOY was I wrong. In this game, you play the owner of a restaurant that has just opened in a skyscraper, and you have to build it up from nothing. When you first start out, it'll be pretty easy. The foods are simple to make and you won't get many customers. Then your first rush hour hits... To make it through this game, you'll need intense focus and memorization skills, as well as great time management skills. Overall, I'd reccommend this game. The graphics are nice, the music is great, and it'll keep you hooked for quite a while. Just try not to play when you're hungry!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013571244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3104, 'last_played': 1428897450}
review:
I haven't played this game since Summer 2014 but I distinctly remember a period of time about a month long (or at least several weeks), where I was playing this game pretty regularly everyday. 

As far as sim games go this one is fun and light and functions moreso around speed and reflexes then one would expect going in. It's rewarding to string together dish after dish and most of the food and other upgrades feel worth (not so much some of the chore upgrades, however). Even little details like going through your email can be enjoyable at times. The way different food combinations on the menu interact can make changing the menu a fun little mini-game (although more often then not the best option is just to build a menu around a number of staple health foods like soups and salads). 

I'm pretty sure most people will reach a point where they're quick reloading their saves as the game more or less demands higher and higher levels of persistent perfection to earn the best cash bonuses and a steady stream of unlockables once you get to the 3 star restaurant and above. 

Around the 4 or 5 star restaurant unlock I reached a point where perfection felt impossible as I juggled increasingly difficult (but pricy) dish upgrades with the looming pressure of the impending lunch/dinner rush crushing down upon me. 

Unless you're a huge fan of the gameplay, progression and eventually punishing challenge of time management and reflexes, you may not get more than a few months of play out of it. Still a 4/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040083751', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1699035162}
review:
First I hesitated to buy this game. But now I regret I didn't buy it before. I've seen many silly restaurant games, but this is certainly not one of them!

It's easy to get into the game but quite a challenge to do well. You have to plan your menu according to daily events. At noon and 6 pm are rush hours and that means quite frantic button mashing (as you add the ingredients by pressing the corrent buttons on the keyboard).  The game has interesting side "quests" like catering events, dating customers (not sure if that would be endorsed in a real restaurant), iron cook challenges, the safety inspector, VIP's just to mention a few. 

The cooking in the game is very simple and not very realistic but it gives inspiration to do the best gourmet food in the universe! Just like at the end of THPS  you would want go out and skate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179734219', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1489307124}
review:
This game... is certainly interesting, and after 1 hour of gameplay I'm gonna write this review. It definitely draws you in, keeping the gameplay long. I went into this game kinda skeptical about it but I began to have fun quickly and found myself wanting to play more and more and conquer "rush-hour" (the time in the game where things are busiest, very hard to keep up) and there is certainly some element of simulator and strategy in this cooking game.

Bad points: I don't have any. The difficulty is... well, difficult as intended and it's kinda fun for all people.

How is this fun? It just is. Recommended.

(First review :D)

+6.28 gallons of Alcohol
+21.20 pounds of Meat
+80.15 pounds of Vegetables
+254.85 pounds of Sugar

Fun and Furious!  I fear playing it any longer in case of a Cook, Serve, Delicious nightmare -runs out of the building-

author: {'steamid': '76561198116514960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1593216909}
review: Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a hardcore restaurant sim, one of the few in its genre that gives players total control over where they want to take their restaurant's future. You'll start with a few thousand dollars and 20 foods to choose from for your menu, as well as a host of restaurant equipment and a virtual email account that connects you to the people of SherriSoda Tower. Nearly everything is unlocked from the start of the game for you to purchase; this is your restaurant, and you must figure out the best strategy to get your business packed with satisfied customers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007607571', 'num_games_owned': 862, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1493749522}
review:
The game I was spying on for so long and never got it until this week Humble Bundle (GO NOW!). Anyway, way it occured to me I might like it is the fact it reminded me of sweet childhood memories of playing Bishi Bashi on Playstation One. Now, Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a bit different, it's part management, part frantic mini game meet skills race against time, part total madness.

You start as low life in fast food industry. You serve crap food, yet decide to call yourself a restaurant owner. Through series of hard grueling tasks such as picking the right cup size for sweet drinks, not overfilling tankards of beer and serving badly burned burgers, you also need to check e-mail, like posts on Facebook, do catering services. Let's not forget washing dishes, cleaning bathrooms and throwing out trash. Each day you have to survive two painful rushours and your customers are total assholes (and alcoholics). 

Apart from main campaign, you'll also try to be the fastest, most efficient chef amongst your Steam buddies and you'll also be able to do magic work against your loved ones in hot seat sessions.

Why you need to get this game?

Because I currently need to play Pillars of Eternity, Witcher 1, Wasteland 2, Running With Rifles, H1Z1, my scores on Pinball Arcade and Pinball FX2 are ultra low, I have to watch new episodes of Better Call Saul and Peaky Blinders, I have several books waiting in queue, need to finish numerous reviews and translate some interviews, yet I go against ALL ODDS and play this game. I even played it today, on my daughter's third birthday. That's HOW GOOD this game is.

review:
Es muy buen juego, entretiene muchisimo y apesar de ser una idea de juego de lo mas sencilla es uno de los mejores que e jugado :D

Basicamente el juego consiste en que tu eres un cocinero con un restaurante el cual tienes que lanzar para que tengas clientela, contra mejor lo hagas mas gente viene y contra peor menos... segun juegas tienes que ir cumpliendo unos requisitos para que tu restaurante sea 5 estrellas (seran las michelin XD ) tambien puedes competir en coop con amigos via local, tienes competiciones entre chefs y tambien tienes para entretenerte desafios semanales :P vamos no es un juegazo de la leche pero pasaras un rato agradable con el, ¿que mas e de decir? le e puesto a probar y e acabado jugando casi 2h xD

Nota final:9/10 (le daria 10 si tuviera español )

author: {'steamid': '76561197995088111', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 1401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1705253847}
review:
Bon petit jeu bien stressant aux heures de pointes, Cook Serve Delicious vous menera du petit café pourri dans un building à un restaurant de luxe 5 étoiles. 
Bien sûr entre ces deux extrêmes, il y'aura du travail à faire, acheter sa nourriture, savoir la préparer rapidement, savoir varier les plats afin de ne pas tomber dans une routine qui nuierait à la réputation de votre restaurant, sans oublier les défis qui vous seront proposés, les combos qu'il y'aura à accomplir , l'équipement à acheter, la vaisselle à faire...
Bref, ce jeu est TRES complet et vraiment jouissif.
Ses deux points noirs sont pour moi sa répétitivité ( je n'y joue pas plus d'une demi-heure par jours sous peine de m'ennuyer ) et son prix:  à l'époque où le site absoluflash existait encore ( RIP ) un petit jeu semblable ( et gratuit )  y existait, proposait grosso modo les mêmes principes, et était aussi complet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048934029', 'num_games_owned': 508, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 3136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1585886607}
review:
If you're looking for a game that requires a certain level of OCD, button mashing and time challenges, this will give you a good run for your money.

Pros:
- Fun, really fun. It is cool to learn recipes and upgrade, to combine various food perks and to balance with the occasional "side quests" all in the line of restaurant duty
- Art style is really enjoyable
- Music and sound effects don't get old, and are actually essential to having a perfect run through, thus challenging both your visual and audio senses!


Cons:
- Limited number of recipes (imo)
- It may start to get slightly repetitive or boring after a while for most people, save for the daily challenges, etc

Overall I'd say that this game is really worth my money, I found it utterly enjoyable, but I do spread out the time I spend playing this to prevent myself from getting too bored by repetition

author: {'steamid': '76561197986918446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1396, 'last_played': 1636336509}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045622288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1578778399}
review: Not the most in-depth experience out there, Cook, Serve, Delicious! proves that sometimes simplicity is the best recipe for fun. It's got a nice artstyle, a quirky sense of humor, and a catchy soundtrack all backing up its rather ingenious gameplay. You play simple microgames in quick sucession, reminscent of WarioWare, themed after restaurant activities: mostly cooking food, but ocasionally doing chores such as cleaning plates or taking our garbage. You have to jugle an increasing number of orders, each order being an individual microgame, at a time. If you leave an order for too long or mess it up, the customer will leave the restaurant unhappy, resulting in less customer flow the following day. The genius is that you set the menu for each day, allowing you to pick and choose your own difficulty. Harder food will usually pay better, but will make it more likely for you to mess up and loose bragging rights. It's really easy to pick up, and surprisingly hard to put down. Huge amounts of fun, I recommend it highly for anyone looking for a game you can easily get stuck playing for way longer than you feel you should.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084762398', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1475, 'last_played': 1502224610}

author: {'steamid': '76561198084544660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1829, 'last_played': 1470211547}
review:
This restaurant simulator was one of the biggest surprises ever, at least for me. I've watched some videos of it, found it quite interesting and when I saw it was on sale on HumbleStore I picked it up and I most definitely do not regret it.

The core of the game is cooking. Customers will come to your establishment, they tell you what they want for food and you prepare it. You do that by pressing buttons that correspond with the ingredients the customers asked for. Say guy wants a hamburger with meat, cheese, tomatoes and pickles. To make that you press M,C,T,P. Sounds quite simple. However, there is a HUGE selection of foods and the cooking process varies drastically.

Some foods require you to put ingredients in specific order, some require cooking certain ingredients individually. Meat for hamburgers must be roasted first, similar thing with meat for nachos (there are 4 types of meat for nachos and 2 types of meat for hamburgers). To make pasta, you need to cook it first and then add the other ingredients etc etc. The variety is astounding and remembering all the buttons for all the ingredients is where this game is so challenging.

The buttons are usually the first letters of the ingredients but not always because some foods have loads of ingredientes, some of which start with the same letter. Pressing O for onions when onions are actually N and O is tomatoes because T is tomato sauce (that's pizza for you in this game) is where you will be doing most mistakes in the beginning. Also you can rebind all the buttons for all the foods individually, big thumbs up for that!

While the game can be very hard, it handles the difficulty very well. You start of with a few ingredients for each food and you can upgrade the foods (and buy new ones) with money you earn throughout the game. This will increase the price of the food but it will also usually make the food more complicated because it will give you additional ingredient(s) and more possible recipes. This way you will learn to prepare the food bit by bit, the game won't throw a lot of new stuff at you out of nowhere. There is also a practice mode for every food and you can even try to cook the food before you buy it so you know what you're getting. If you plan to finish the game though, you will need to learn pretty much all the foods anyway.

And that's how it goes, you build your menu and work for a day. After work you spend the money on stuff you need, pick new foods for your menu (or keep the old ones) and do another day. This routine is broken up by events like catering, where you prepare foods with a certain theme (snacks, italian food, drinks etc), bets (someone can bet you can't make 30 perfect orders while having pizza and icecream on your menu, for example. If you beat it, you get extra cash) and other events, most of which will require you to have specific foods on your menu (dating and VIP).

There is also a challenge mode with online leaderboards where you compete with other people online, you can play the campaign in local co-op where one person is expediting the orders and one is preparing them.

Overall, there is plenty of content in the game to keep you entertained for quite some time. Definitely pick it up if you see it on sale, but it's worth it even for a full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961221174', 'num_games_owned': 2276, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 6338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1651618565}
review:
Although many "hardcore" gamers would discount this as a mobile game ported to PC - and a stupid one - I think it deserves some credit. 

CSD certainly won't teach you how to cook, but it holds value as a mental workout. Succeeding at this game requires memorization - both muscle memory and traditional - in addition to being able to quickly read onscreen instructions and translate them into keyboard shortcuts in order to properly fill the customer orders.

Each "food" or menu item, once upgraded all the way (for absurd amounts of money) individually holds the potential for dozens of "recipe" possibilities. In addition to this you maintain a menu of 6 of these items and have to be able to do any of them at any given time. This will exercise your mind and your fingers.

The game also features extra challenges, some of which are mandatory to complete story mode, that further accentuate the mental exercises presented normally in the game. Overall, you must also manage your restaurant's menu in order to generate "buzz", thus increasing your popularity and daily income. 

While it's not a hardcore restaurant simulator, it's still a good way to stay focused when you wake up on the weekend and can't think straight yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032128945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1593, 'last_played': 1425817899}
review: In Cook, Serve, Delicious; you are the manager/short order chef/dishwasher/Charlie Day of a walk up restaurant in an office building.  You get to select the menu each day and work your way up from a one star to platinum five-star restaurant by meeting certain targets.  You can buy and upgrade the foods you put on the menu and as your restaurant progresses more of the luxury foods become available and some of the basic foods become unavailable.  For example you can't buy lobster in a one-star restaurant, and sadly can't serve a corndog in a five-star restaurant.  You prepare the foods through one or more phases of keystrokes modified by the specific orders desired by the customers. in multiple phase recipes there are interstitial periods of cooking for a certain amount of time, if you exceed the amount of time for cooking a food you may burn it or it may go bad from being held too long.  Additional time restrictions come from the customers only waiting a certain amount of time for you to start their order; and the need to take care of chores such as doing the dishes, taking out the trash, and setting mouse traps.  In it's essence it's a typing game, with a lot of short term time management. If you don't touch type you'll probably have a tough time in the later game.  When you are getting through a lunch rush and moving from order to order though, it ends up feeling more like a rhythm game.  I found it highly engaging and to perform well you have to focus very intently in much the same way needed in playing a bullet hell shoot-em up.  The game has recently added multi-player functionality and online leader-board challenges, but having only played the single player campaign I can't speak to how good those features are. When I saw this game initially I thought it fun, but it ended up being way more entertaining and engrossing than I expected.  I'd give it a 9/10 and a definite recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1496, 'last_played': 1425767263}
review:
What an awesome game, this is the sort of game that you can keep installed and keep dropping in for five minutes at a time. I couldn't do long stints playing but I have put a lot of time into CSD.

It's basically one large, long QTE, but done very well. Simply press the buttons in the correct order to cook and serve various different foods. There is plenty of customization here, buying different kitchen appliances to help make more complex meals, along with things like dishwashers to sort out the chores for you. 

A really well thought out game that you can get really cheaply but still put tons of hours into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002841437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1528065597}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a mix of casual appearance and hardcore gameplay. You play as the owner/chef of a restaurant and it’s your job to make the food. You get a constant influx of customers and serving them gets enjoyably chaotic, especially during rush hour.

There’s loads of other stuff to it, like buying/upgrading food, buying appliances, special events, etc. This means the experience is constantly changing and stays interesting.

You choose the menu for each day, so you can have lots of complicated and expensive items, or lots of easy and cheap items, or a combination of the two. Which is nice, because you essentially set the difficult for yourself.

You begin as a zero-star restaurant and then do tasks to get upgraded through the stars, which also unlocks jobs/items/upgrades/extras. It’s all very well designed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092499925', 'num_games_owned': 595, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1624624198}
review: Really fun and fast paced, a must have if you like any game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198084891266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1452238403}
review:
Single sentence review: The zaniest and most challenging restaurant sim slash time management game you will ever come across on Steam.

Cook Serve Delicious is an incredibly fun, potentially maddening cooking/restaurant "sim" - although using that word to describe it is doing a disservice. While you do indeed play owner and choose the menu, check your emails and so on (some of the emails are hilarious by the way!), the core focus of the gameplay boils down to you as chef. From open to close, it's your job to multi-task your customer's orders, using keyboard hotkeys to manage up to eight (!) dishes simultaneously. Cook each one with no mistakes and get them out on time to rack up your combo, win bets, unlock cool stuff and eventually showcase your talents in front of a culinary secret society! I'm not joking.

Now. This game may look like another Diner Dash, but considering that some dishes use nearly every single letter (A-Z) on the keyboard plus the arrow keys and space bar, this game can reach a level of difficulty which will have even the most hardcore time-management fans palpitating. Combine this with a realistic peak time mechanic, your food choices having a PROFOUND effect on how the day will pan out, needing to compelete chores simultaneously alongside your cooking to stop bad publicity, navigating ever more complex bets from Crazy Dave or an orange robot to boost funding to your restaurant, and suddenly needing to respond to a potential girlfriend/boyfriend's crappy chat-up lines in the middle of a five second flash-fry...

... yeah. This game can get as hectic and random as all hell, but it is one of the richest and most challenging time-management games I have ever played and I cannot recommend it enough. I would especially recommend it if you have never felt challenged by a time management game before. Too many games in that genre go down the route of being too easy, doing lots of hand-holding or very quickly running out of new features to keep you interested. Cook Serve Delicious manages to deliver on all of those aspects while remaining colourful and wacky enough to stop you from throwing your laptop at a concrete wall.

Bon appétit!

author: {'steamid': '76561198033491638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2064, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1840, 'last_played': 1500202775}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045398076', 'num_games_owned': 315, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1470763564}
review:
I just love when a game like this trick me on trying it and then crawls under my skin.
Casual? There's nothing casual about this game. This game is SUPER HARD! And I mean that in most positive way.
You're in charge of a new 0 star restaurant and your mission is to reach 5 star rank.
There is the managing part where you buy foods and equipment necessary for your restaurant to operate and juggle them around for best buzz bonuses (% of how hip you restaurant is, how crowded it will be the next day).
And then there is the action part where you serve your customers from 9AM ti 10PM. That is the SUPER HARD part (especially if you made crappy decisions during managing part and even more challenging if you're not a proficient typist) as you'll have to be super quick on your keyboard (you can play with mouse, but it's lot more efficient not to) if you want to serve most of the customers and you have to make quick decisions like which customer to serve first and read quickly what the actual order is (every food type has many variations when it comes to receipts).
Now at this point you can probably think that this game can be frustrating, and I pleased to say that no matter how hard it is, it NEVER gets frustrating. Yeah that one order you screwed up will kill your chances of a perfect day, yeah there will be times when you don't know what buttons are you hitting from all the madness, but all this will not make you mad as tomorrow is a new day and new opportunities. :)
The gameplay don't get boring as every day there is something new, a new food, a new upgrade, a new situation to deal with, etc.
And the developer who already put so much love and effort into this game is constantly improving it. The current version of the game is Battle Kitchen Edition, which added the multiplayer mode, lots of interesting competitive challenges and a harder difficulty (if you ask me, this game needs an Easy difficulty so that a wider audience could be approached).

The fun never ends with Cook, Serve, Delicious!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001534970', 'num_games_owned': 1454, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1494795620}
review: Cook, Serve, Delicious! est un titre vraiment sympathique qui mettra vos nerfs à rudes épreuves ! Pas bien compliqué au début, le titre gagnera en complexité au fur et à mesure que votre restaurant évoluera. Plus de recettes complexes, plus de clientèle, qui devient exigeante en fonction de l'orientation du restaurant... Vous devrez gérer votre stress et faire le boulot rapidement, mais proprement, pour ne pas voir votre resto se faire descendre par les organismes de contrôles et/ou par la clientèle, qui ne se gênera pas pour lâcher un avis négatif sur internet. Un titre à consommer sans modération, surtout à ce prix !

author: {'steamid': '76561197974376312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1055, 'last_played': 1505645360}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious ist ein super Spiel für Zwischendurch, wie auch um länger Zeit damit verbringen zu können. 
Am Anfang des Spiels wird man langsam mit der Spielmechanik vertraut gemacht und es geht auch noch eher gemütlich zur Sache. Sobald Sie dann aber selber entscheiden können welche Rezepte/Food-Uprgrades Sie in Ihrem Tagesmenü verwenden möchten steigt der Schwierigkeitsgrad kontinuierlich an. Richtig lustig wird es ab dem Zeitpunkt sobald Sie noch mehr Bestellslots erhalten, das heisst Sie müssen noch einen Kunden mehr bedienen was das Ganze auch nicht einfacher macht.Durch die selbständige Auswahl der Speisen auf Ihrer Menükarte können Sie jedoch den Schwierigkeitsgrad ein bisschen entschärfen. Optisch finde ich ist das Spiel gut gelungen für diese Art Genre, man erkennt was man kocht und zubereitet, jedoch werden Sie ziemlich schnell keine Zeit mehr haben um sich um die Optik Ihrer Speisen zu kümmern. Das Upgrade System ist ein weiterer Leckerbissen, da Ihre Speisen nicht nur um Zutaten, sondern auch um Rezepte erweitert werden. Auch gibt es Upgrades um z. B. schneller abzuwaschen oder den Müll einfacher zu entsorgen und glauben Sie mir, Sie werden diese Upgrades mit Handkuss nehmen. Damit das Spiel nicht eintönig wird gibt es auch Spezial-Events die Sie bewältige n müssen um so Ihre Sterne Bewertung erhöhen zu können. Einerseits sind dies Cateringaufträge, später folgen Kochbattles und diese sind meiner Meinung richtig heftig.

PRO
Für zwischendurch, auch Langzeitmotivation
Nette Aufmachung
Viele verschiedene Rezepte
Online Modus

CONTRA
Sound durchschnittlich ( ändert jedoch nichts am Spielspass)
Wenig Upgrades um z. B Abwasch zu erleichtern

Fazit
Ich kann das Spiel nur weiter empfehlen, denke Leute welche bereits ähnliche Spiele auf Ihrem Smartphone gespielt haben werden an Cook, Serve, Delicious richtig Freude haben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126764770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1487612771}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045882856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1454977477}
review:
This game is intense.  It is challenging for a guy like me who likes turn based games.  I think it would give you a run for your money even if you are a speed champion.  It's fun and what keeps me coming back is the extra game modes and things to unloick.

I have been playing on the Linux version.  I have it installed on a Ubuntu 14.04.1 fork.  It goes HD fullscreen no problem and looks good too.  I have a generic xbox controller and it can't detect it for some reason.  It seems like the game would be fun to play with a controller.  I think the best control scheme is with a keyboard anyway.  Trying to play with a mouse would be difficult, it's just not fast enough.  Other than not detecting my controller it runs very smooth and I have not discovered any other bugs yet.

HIghly recommend, especially if you need something to keep you from falling asleep.  Fast and fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043250032', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 329, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 566, 'last_played': 1424194091}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a restaurant/cooking simulator where you start with a rundown little cafe and turn it into a five star restaurant all the while cooking numerous dishes, fending off robbers and flushing blocked toilets. While the game might not sound like everyone's cup of tea it combines addictive gameplay with a good progression system to make a  fun gaming experience. As a huge fan of the Papa's Pizzeria games this was a must buy for me and I was not disappointed.

+Nice simplistic graphics, food and drink is well designed and the UI is nice to look at as well
+Incredibly addictive, simple gameplay that keeps you coming back for more
+You can take place in bets each day which require you to get a certain combo with certain foods
+You are rewarded for perfect orders and penalised for bad orders which helps push you to try as hard as you can
+Lots of different dishes including drinks
+Most dishes have upgrades which adds a new ingredient and new recipe cards
+All recipe cards have specific names
+Local co-op game mode
+The hotkeys for the different ingredients are for the most part intuitive, i.e. the first letter of the ingredient is the hotkey, and if you don't like them the hotkeys can be edited
+Full controller support for both the Xbox 360 Controller and the Dualshock 4 Controller
+Great music
+There are special events in the game which you can take part in such as catering events which earn you more money

-The frequency of work orders (flushing the toilet, cleaning the dishes, taking out the trash and setting rat traps) seemed a bit too high, in particular the flushing the toilet job seemed to be very frequent even when the toilet had been upgraded
-The progression on the star system is very slow and food upgrades are very expensive
-Once you start unlocking more order slots (you start with four and then it increases) it becomes increasingly difficult to keep track of all of the orders you have on the go and I often pressed the wrong key and sent out an order early, breaking a combo
-I had a couple of issues where I lost saves and had to replay about 2 hours worth
-You can't upgrade the appearance of your restaurant apart from the automatic changes when you get a new star 

Verdict:
7

A great restaurant/cooking sim that is perfect for fans of similar games but might be quite boring for most, best to pick this up on sale.

El K.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072062230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1591313149}

All in all, Cook, Serve, Delicious is a fantastic game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085123827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1424056047}
review:
Excellent game! I just played it for hours. It's roughly like Diner Dash, but way more invovled. I like that it's repetitve enough that you can memorize certain tasks (so the game doesn't feel impossible!) but not so repetitve that it turns into a rote timing game (like Diner Dash can). Most items can have multiple recipes (which you can get by purchasing upgrades as you go along) which keeps the novelty factor alive and continues making it challenging for a long time. 

I also like that the customers don't really get impatient like they do in DD - items have a wait time in the queue and will contribute to a bad score if you don't get to the fast enough, but it's not like DD where certain people are more annoyed than others. Similarly, I like that you can get an order kinda wrong and it doesn't really penalize you. You wouldn't get a perfect score, but the customer isn't angry either. (If you give them the entirely wrong order, they will be mad, of course, but if you just forget one ingredient or something, they're just mildly annoyed).

Another cool feature is that you don't have to use your mouse (unless you really want to) but instead can use keystrokes for everything. The default keystrokes are pretty self-explanatory (c for creamer, s for sugar, etc), or else easily learnable (n for onion, v for olive). And if you just can't rememeber them... they let you change the default keystrokes, per food, to whatever you want them to be. Love how flexible that system is!

Besides being like a highly improved Diner Dash, this game also has a touch of Tycoon in it as well, which I love. They did a good job of giving you warnings of things (Rainy day coming! May want to have rainy day food on the menu!), but still not making it super tedious (for example, you only have to buy equipment and recipes, but don't have to keep on eye on / purchase supplies). They have a health inspector that comes every 5 days, but all she checks is that you're cleaning the toilet, etc. Since you know ahead of time that she's coming, you can opt for an easy menu that day to save yourself some time and make sure you get her demands met.

There are also some interesting side options you can do. There are occasional bets you can take (or not) that can make you some extra cash. You can also take catering jobs once you've upgraded a bit for some SUPER easy cash. :) And if you happen to have a perfect day (I've only managed this once so far!) you get a cash bonus for that as well.

I definitely recommend this game! It's straightforward enough to have zero learning curve (and they even allow you to repeat tutorials anytime you want to learn the different recipes!), but it's complex enough to not get boring and to give yourself something to work towards (gotta buy that pizza oven!).

(PS: The only real downside I found was when the robber comes. I've only had that happen once but it was during rush hour and giving a description to the police was pretty tedious so I lost several food orders b/c I couldn't get to them fast enough (also there was a time limit on the description-giving and I didn't do it fast enough because I was distracted by my food burning so... I didn't get the report filed quick enough to get my money back! Boo....) Luckily the robber doesn't seem to come often and I also noticed some upgrades you can buy to make him even less so.... yeah....)

author: {'steamid': '76561198014763869', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2447, 'last_played': 1494459272}
review: Brought this game not expecting much but it is so much fun!  I love how flowy it is, effortless to jump into the game but frustrating if you're a perfectionist looking to get the high scores and perfect day rewards.  Just amazing!  I loved the PC version so much I brought the app too just to give extra love to the developer.  (The app also runs super smooth.)  Thank you for making such a wonderful fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026996489', 'num_games_owned': 4628, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1423716826}
review:
This game was a huge surprise,  and is an enjoyable time management cooking game.
There is a main story campaign where you start off with basics and a few recipes and as you earn money and reputation you can buy more equipment and add new recipes.
The game can get quite hectic as there are times where you not only have to serve many customers at once but see to the restaurants other business such as making sure the toilets are cleaned, the trash is taken out, especially at the beginning where you have to do everything yourself.  

You can try out recipes before you buy them, each recipe fulfills some customers needs such as party, healthy or on a budget (just a couple of examples) so there is strategy to your menu planning.

As well as the story there is a local multiplayer option, you can use keyboard, mouse or gamepad controls.
There are multiple save slots if you want to play a few games paralllel .  There are weekly challenges.

With 52 Steam achievements and trading cards, if you are a TM fan what are you waiting for?

author: {'steamid': '76561198112106319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2214, 'last_played': 1672536536}
review:
This is the most intense cooking game I've ever played. Perfect for hardcore and casual audiences alike, this game will have you screaming obscenities at items of food for hours on end.

FLUSH A TOILET! GET ROBBED, THEN WATCH AS IMPATIENT ASSHOLES BECOME ANGRY THAT THEY AREN'T BEING SERVED! DATE EVERYONE! TAKE PART IN A SECRET COOKING TOURNAMENT RUN BY NINJAS! PUT RAW FRIES IN A BOWL AND BE UNABLE TO PUT THEM BACK IN THE DEEP FRIER!

Fun for the whole family.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025055095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 21019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5325, 'last_played': 1691139257}

author: {'steamid': '76561198109297375', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 2485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1456221026}
review:
Although this game looks casual, believe me, it is not. It's challenging, humorous, and content wise - full. The main mode plus all the challenges will keep you occupied for many, many hours. I've owned this game on Android since its release and I can tell you that the Steam version is superior (doh!). It has the addition of local multiplayer, and weekly challenges.

In my experience, some things (recipes) in this game are easier on touch devices, and some of them are easier on a keyboard (yes, you can play with a controller, but it is waaay more difficult than playing with a keyboard).

I encourage you to try this game. You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019569796', 'num_games_owned': 638, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1422055829}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! te pone al mando de un restaurante que acaba de abrir. Tu misión es elegir el menú, mejorar las instalaciones y, por supuesto, preparar la comida lo mejor que puedas... a toda velocidad. El tiempo apremia, y es tu deber llenar los estómagos de todo aquel que visite tu establecimiento si quieres buenas críticas y más clientes.

El juego se basa en la idea de escuchar atentamente lo que quiere el cliente y preparar su plato con la mayor rapidez posible sin descuidar el resto de tareas de tu establecimiento... y al resto de clientes. Cada tecla se corresponde a un ingrediente, y es tu deber memorizar cuál es cuál para preparar la comida lo más rápido posible. Cuantos más platos prepares sin equivocarte y sin que un cliente se marche insatisfecho porque su comida no estaba a tiempo, más dinero ganarás.

Puedes emplear este dinero para mejorar tus platos (más ingredientes y más dificultad, pero mayores ingresos) o tus instalaciones (por ejemplo comprando una freidora que te permite servir más platos o un bote de propinas que te permite ganar más dinero si haces las cosas bien).

Si necesitas un juego para pasar el rato, es muy divertido. No esperes mucha profundidad y no le eches muchas horas seguidas porque su planteamiento es bastante repetitivo y puede llegar a ser desesperante según los platos que escojas preparar cada día.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157473603', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1768, 'last_played': 1701597743}
review:
Okay, so 19 hours in to my Cook, Serve, Delicious! experience and I am a 4 star restaurant. Getting a perfect day at this stage is incredibly rare (for me, atleast) and for some odd reason I feel GUILT whenever I produce a bad order. That's a good thing though, made me want to play more. On top of all that, I think it's making me very crazy.

+Great workout for your fingers
+Fast-paced fun
+Addicting soundtrack (seriously)
+A lot of food to prepare, alongside lots of achievements (who doesn't like those!?)


-Can be a tad repetitive
-Stressful at times
-The only time I have ever hated Pizza
-Would have been nice to customise the restaurant and make it 'mine'

author: {'steamid': '76561198079125980', 'num_games_owned': 1376, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1640746017}
review:
very rarely does a game hit a new niche in my library i never knew i even wanted.

CSD does that. while ive admittedly not played this game to the extent id like to, there is massive potential for this game. the competitive modes are really intriguing, as well as the story mode.

This game has a HUGE skill curve, especially later on. It doesnt get into the minutae of restuarant work, avoiding needing to supply your resturant, set it up, etc. its all based on your skill/concentration level.

The game also helps you improve keyboard dexterity, while it may be a grind at times when you play it, its hard to put it down after a few in game days.

well worth a buy, check it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035477587', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1621934748}
review:
Se você quer testar suas habilidades e reflexos com o teclado, você achou o que procurava.
Pode parecer um jogo básico de culinária, mas na verdade é um grande desafio pro seu cérebro.

Desafia, e muito, sua capacidade de fazer duas (ou mais) coisas ao mesmo tempo, com uma gameplay diferente e satisfatória.

Você nunca vai se sentir tão bem ao ver um cliente indo embora satisfeito.

O jogo é difícil do começo ao fim, e o nível de dificuldade nos níveis finais é algo absurdo.
Só muito treino e reflexos de gato para conseguir um restaurante 5 estrelas com esse jogo

Vale cada centavo.

review:
Sure, it seems so simple. It seems so easy. It seems so.... well, unexciting. But this game is addictive as #*%^.

While it may appear to be nothing more than a Flash game, its simplicity is what makes it so challenging. Slowly but surely, your restaurant becomes harder to run. But even when it's a bit frustrating, it's still fun. And addictive as #*%^.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078519628', 'num_games_owned': 1563, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 1559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1527404928}
review:
Jesus christ, I used to work at a restaurant, one of the worst jobs I had, I always came home stinking like raw fish and in never ending agony, I come home, and I play this game....Just to cook fish over and over. I breathe fish, I eat fish, I bleed fish, I'm sick of fish. This game keeps that hate alive!

Plus, rush hours....I've got PTSD flashbacks when I go through one in this game, almost to the point of suffering anxiety attacks. PLEASE BE PATIENT SIR, WE'VE GOT FUCKING 30 COSTUMERS WAITING FOR THEIR FOOD ALREADY, OH NO, ANOTHER WAVE OF COSTUMERS, MAKE IT STAAAAAHP!

After playing this for a few hours, I've got some questions, though.

Is your restaurant so short of supplies, that if you accidentally put ice when a costumer didn't want it....You can't get rid of the ice? You will have to deal with angry costumers instead of wasting precious ice and soda. That will teach you to pay attention!

Why do costumers complain about, say, getting a jumbo soda when they asked for a medium or large? I mean, it's like, more for less, they still pay the same. WHY?

How the hell can you enchance the flavor of plain ass water with flavor blast? 

And....How the fuck does a costumer know if I slapped their meat 5 times instead of 6?!?!?

.......Get this game, and you'll probably end up being addicted to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104554149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2122, 'last_played': 1658307041}
review: This game is one of those games that just gets ignored for some reason, seriously why? It's a great game that has a low point of entry and a super high skill cap. This game is for people who enjoy getting good at a game or people who enjoy learning new games and then stopping becuase it's both. The game can be very easy at first where you're making pretzels and corndogs while pouring some beer and occasionally flushing a few toilets here and there but, let me tell ya, getting to a platinium star resturant and trying to serve fried rice, sushi, bananas foster, soup, kebabs and steak is really hard and that is what i tried. To put it in perspective 31 hours of playing and being somewhat good isn't enough to be good enough to do that. So go crazy and try to make it to those leaderboards, i got 40th on last week's challenge so i'm pretty sure everyone else can get atleast to 40th right? because if you don't beat me you're a scrub becuase i'm a scrub.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105826520', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1556528357}
review:
5/5 Stars

Cook, Serve, Delicious is a strangely addicting game and i would reccomend it to anyone who likes food and having fun for hours at a time. CSD can also be classed as a memory based game because remembering all the different condiments for the different dishes can be difficult when under the pressure of rush hour which happens twice a day!
The art style of CSD is unique and cool because it looks painted which i quite like.
All in all a fun casual game to past the time

PS: Controller recomended

author: {'steamid': '76561197998365562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1579, 'last_played': 1468850451}
review:
this game is so good. people always laugh at this game because i guess the title "cook, serve, delicious" is kinda funny and cheesy, and they always assume it'll be some boring restaurant sim or something. this is actually a typing based rhythm game where every food item is a little rhythm minigame where certain actions and ingredients correspond to keys on the keyboard, and you get bonus points for how accurate you are to the orders, and following recipes correctly. if you're a fan of rhythm games or typing games at all you'll probably be into this. i've been aching for a game like this for ages personally, as a fan of stuff like guitar hero, and as someone who's pretty good at and enjoys typing. 

there's a single player campaign mode where you choose restaurant items and make money each day, and buy new equipment/menu items and stuff, and the "battle kitchen" mode which is just like a challenge mode. there's endurance challenges where you see how long you can last without messing up an order, and speed challenges where you do a sequence of orders as fast as you can. there's online leaderboards for all the stuff in battle kitchen. i mostly play endurance challenges.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980661379', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1612, 'last_played': 1480793636}
review: I was a crazy surprised how fun this was. I bought it after watching some dude play it on Twitch, because it looked like an interesting, new form of gameplay. It plays kind of like a memory/reflex game, and the charm of the artwork really kind of makes you feel like a short-order cook. Definitely give it a whirl if you're looking for something different to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030848108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1511843166}
review: A fun and challenging time management game for running a little cafe in an office building.  Easy to get started, but difficult to master.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975072393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1481484805}
review: The precision and speed of keyboard use in this game makes [i]Starcraft[/i] look like [i]World of Warcraft[/i].

author: {'steamid': '76561198003492336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1438025814}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! is an easy to learn but hard as hell to master type of game. 

You go through your culinary career from a zero star rat-hole to a glorious five star world famous restaurant.

Personally, I played this for while. And I can tell you I enjoyed every second of that while. 

The graphics are cartoony so I can't say anything negative about them since I like the idea/concept of cartoonish things overall.

You can make maaany different foods and this game will quite possibly make you hungry. 

I give this game a 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971101812', 'num_games_owned': 758, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 1240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1451256173}
review:
This game is HOOD. 

Its pretty hardcore, has a lot of content, I'm 18 hours in and I'm not even half way there. It has steam leaderboards, weakly challenges, has a bout +70 types of good total I think. Its pretty damn good, if you like what you see, and want to play or see more well whaddya waiting for? 

+ Ryan Davis is mentioned in this game.

This game is pretty well ported to PC as well, you can select keyboard controls, or gamepad controls with Xbox 360, Playstation OR even XBOX 1 gamepad layouts which is... like why isnt this option on every god damn game? Everything about the game is god damn good. The Soundtrack, the writing, even the god damn spam emails.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086313723', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2966, 'last_played': 1424184519}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! is the most fun cooking simulation casual game I ever played. It's more fun to play it than Hotdog Bush. Not gonna compare this with Diner Dash and it's spin-offs because that's a totally other game.

This game made my hands move faster and made my head ache because of the stress it gives me. Nonetheless, I had fun playing it and reaching all of its achievements is really crazy, crazy in a good way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058129745', 'num_games_owned': 611, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1499382115}
review: This game is recommended if you don't mind having blackouts of time. Turning off the game takes hours because you won't want to stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035054806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 2268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1420840928}
review:
Ok it's hard to describe why this game is enjoyable.

It's nothing like real cooking. Trust me I've gone to school for that stuff as well as worked for 3 1/2 years in the industry. It's really not realistic.

It's mostly a timed key puncher game. Hit the right keys per menu choice when ordered. Hit the right order number when the cooking time is ready. Try and keep the wait time down so they down't walk away. Hit the right keys to clean dishes, ect.. Turn up the intensity and complete the cateering challenges. Oh and you can't get to 3 stars without doing that.

It's nothing like real cooking WHAT SO EVER....

Yet somehow.. it's fun slamming the perfect order of nachos with over 20 possible variables down and getting a customer thumbs up. A perfect order day is bliss. Passing health inspection days a relief.

And oddly enough it can give you a non drug indused case of the munchies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050918249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1415611107}
review: I couldn't play this game at all.  I HATED it and I love time management games.  To the people who can play this one, I commend you.  It moved at the speed of light within five minutes of starting.  I guess I should have listened to people when they said it was more hardcore.  I just don't have the patience.  There is a place to learn how to put things together, but I honestly couldn't be bothered over something like this - it just annoyed me very quickly.  Maybe I will give it a go some other time - but for now, no thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019173178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1088, 'last_played': 1595881706}
review:
Thinking about Cook, Serve, Delicious, I wish there was a third option in terms of my recommendation: a sideways thumb. Before I begin, I would like to admit I have a fake food fetish. Wooden toy sushi rolls, plastic hamburgers that can be assembled, lego food. It all stirs my imagination and I often find lingering over these items when I encounter them if out holiday shopping for nieces and nephews. So the premise, setting and aesthetics of most any cooking sim definitely attracts me.

Now on to this game itself:

I've seen CSD described as a "hardcore cooking/restaurant" sim. It's not though.

The game boils down to an ellaborate typing and algorithm test. The restaurant and cooking simulation gets a bit weird when soup reveals itself to be one of the most complex dishes to prepare in the game, as you are tasked with prepping each order for soup from scratch.

One missed keystroke not only spoils a dish but you are forced to serve the meal to the customer even though you've cuaght the error. There is no option to "start over" at a hit for time and or money spent on wasted food.

In my mind, a real 1st person hardcore restaurant sim would challenge you to manage time, like choosing to prep veg and make a new pot of soup prior to lunch rushes. To anticipate and use down time strategically between meals. You might even get a sous chef or kitchen hand who can help chop carrots, etc. or maybe you need to send them to the nearest market because your kitchen just ran out of cream or butter (as sometimes happens in the real world!).

It's not that I want a restaurant sim that is as so close to reality that it would fit in with titles such as "Farming Simulator 2015." I think an ideal title in this genre could still have the same pace of gameplay that this first iteration of Cook Serve Delicious has, but I would like to see a little more nuance in the structure of the day and the gameplay throughout the day other than a speed challenge to mash buttons with no planning or strategy. For gods' sake, at least make a pot of soup serve 6-10 customers!

Short of it, I think the cooking game genre still has a ways to go. There is room out there for a true "hardcore cooking & restauarant sim." But despite it's charms, CSD is not that title for me.

(That being said, I've become something of an achievement hound as of late and I will likely continue to play the game, at least till I hit around 50% completion.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198139403654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1350, 'last_played': 1420847646}
review:
Excelente jogo, altamente viciante.
Trata-se de um jogo de simulação e gerenciamento de um restaurante. No começo você tem um restaurante pobre e simples, porém, se você cumprir todos os objetivos você ganha a primeira estrela e assim por diante, até transformar seu restaurante em um cinco estrelas. E após conseguir isso o jogo continua a te dar objetivos para transformar o seu restaurante em sucesso mundial!
Não tenha dúvidas em em comprar esse jogo, vale cada centavo.
Nota 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198018011907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1515146327}
review:
By Gordon Ramsay's scrambled eggs, this is an addictive game if there ever was one.

Seriously, when you go to bed at night and you see lasagna dishes and deep fried chicken soaring in front of your eyes as you drift off to sleep, you know you've played one hour too many Cook, Serve, Delicious. (Or you may have some serious health issues, please consult your doctor.)

It's a very simple concept. Cook dishes, serve them to customers before they get cranky, and work your way up to a five star restaurant. You cook dishes by pressing the right keys in rapid succession and serving them before they burn. Keep customers happy and they'll keep coming back for more; forget to chop the head off their cooked fish and they might not pay. Or come back. Ever. If you keep the customers happy, more will come and before you know it you're layering lasagna at 500 keystrokes/second, and you'll love it. With the money you earn you can buy new recipes or upgrade recipes you already have. Or upgrade your toilets so they're more accustomed to your customers' special needs. Seriously, I don't know what they're doing in there that obligates you to go in there and fix them every other hour.

In short:

Pros
- Highly addictive
- Each recipe has its own unique manner of preparation
- Very satisfying sound effects when you're preparing your dishes (Yeah, that's right. Slap that patty on that bun.)
- Oddly relaxing

Cons
- Crappy, crappy toilets
- Exhaustible number of recipes
- Kind of loses its charm once you pass the four star mark
- Why are these people ordering beers at 9 AM?

author: {'steamid': '76561197987806981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1504927530}
review:
You can go from 'zen' to 'super competitive' in this game, as your performance dictates the diffiulty of your serving days.  The beginning may seem simple, but you can really quickly challenge yourself by putting complex-to-create dishes on your menu.  Make money, serve customers, and even date people on your quest to become a 5-star establishment!  

Once you complete the main story line (which I haven't, in almost 20 hours of gameplay), there are weekly 'challenges' that really test your mettle in the kitchen.  

This game is really an easy to play, difficult to master style that can satisfy anyone.  Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981005856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1696, 'last_played': 1416603974}
review:
[h1]COOK, SERVE, DELICIOUS![/h1]

Restaurant action-sim that requires you remain cool under pressure and have fast fingers.

7/10

Purchased For: Free

Cook, Serve, Delicious is at times an intense and high paced experience. You start with a run down restaurant that needs money, a lot of money, to improve. From new equipment that opens up new recipes to improving the decor and facilities. 

It starts at a relatively easy pace serving simple staple such as corn dogs and beer to a small number of customers. These customers come in slowly at first as you build up buzz about your new restaurant after all no one wants to eat at a run down place they've never heard of before. Each order requires you to give the customer exactly what they want as fast as possible, making sure they don't wait too long and you don't over/under cook their order. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=331620355

This is where the difficulty comes in, each order must be prepared by pressing the responding key that matches the food type. To create something simple like a corn dog you only have to press either M for mustard or K for ketchup or if the customer has no taste both. It seems simple and it is, however this simplicity doesn't last long. As both your restaurant and equipment improve so does the difficulty. Along with the restaurant improvements comes new customers with more refined palates, they no longer want corn dogs and beer but steak, soup and fine wine. These fine foods are more complicated to make are require a good memory, fast fingers and attention to detail. So for example a customer will order lasagne that requires you to press P-S-M-C-R twice followed by P-S-M-C, one mistake or slip and the order is ruined, take more than a few seconds and orders will be missed.

Days are broken up into five parts, the early part of the day will see a small number of customers then the rush hour at lunch time hits, you’ll need to be on your a-game to make it through before another lull as you prepare for the dinner rush-hour and finally after that the wind down before closing time. Deciding what dishes to put on the menu will make or break your day, too many complicated dishes will attract more people but will prove difficult to satisfy every order during rush hour, however too simple a menu and you won't attract enough people nor make enough money. Thrown into this mix are odd-jobs such as cleaning the plates, cleaning the toilet and taking out the trash, simple jobs but they are usually thrown at you when you least want or expect them and can seriously throw a spanner into what was a successful rush-hour.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=334495804

At the end of each day you get to prepare for the next one, buying new equipment, reading emails, accepting challenges, laying bets on your cooking skills and creating a new menu. There's a far bit of grind as you're required to complete 20 days before you can upgrade to the next restaurant. However it's very addictive and the game makes sure you're always busy with rarely chance to stop and think as you try and achieve a day of perfect orders. There's no great depth to Cook, Serve, Delicious other than the constant actions-per-minute mechanic but that's the attraction, nailing a perfect day on extreme difficulty is an exhilarating and satisfying experience. For many people who fold under pressure, have slow fingers or a bad memory then the heat of the kitchen will prove to be too great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090578092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1233, 'last_played': 1590211894}
review:
I bought this game much to the amusement of my fiance and roommate who thought it was going to be a silly cooking game like DinerDash. Then the roommate watched me play through a few days in my 0-star restaurant and he was all, "That looks ridiculously hard!" 
"It is!" I replied, furiously tip-typing on my keyboard, trying to remember the hotkeys mapped to each ingredient. ...And then I typed 'M' for Mushroom, when really 'M' is for Meatball and 'U' is for Mushroom and I ruined the order while rats were trying to eat my food and toilets weren't being flushed because really, what sort of customer does a 0-star restaurant invite? PEOPLE WHO DON'T FLUSH, I GUESS...though now even in my world-class restaurant, I am STILL flushing toilets. Filthy rich people. 

*ahem*
This game is great. It even has a way to compete against other Steam players in weekly challenges AND you can connect other players at home with controllers to play against your friends/hobo alliances/enemies/whatever. It's super stressful, but in a good way-- like, "FINALLY! I DID IT AND IT WAS AMAZING!" sort of stressful. 

<3 <3 <3 Best $3.99 I've ever spent on a game. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198024795174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1708925758}
review:
Amazingly relaxing and stressful at the same time!
Cook serve delicious is the perfect game to test your memory and multitasking skills, Also be sure to eat before playing this game because you WILL get Very hungry! I've seen people play this on Youtube and don't be fooled by its simple looking gameplay because it will become very challenging! Luckily with a bit of practice and ways slow down orders you will eventually get the hang of it. I rate this game 10/10!

author: {'steamid': '76561198080111931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1417862311}

author: {'steamid': '76561198104524581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3661, 'last_played': 1554101834}
review:
This is for me to practice writing in English.
I apologize in advance if my grammar or English is not right :)

Oh, how I love to cook!

This is one of my favorite cooking pc games that literally makes me hungry for food day and night.
It also lets me experience or atleast gives me an idea of being an aspiring top chef with owning a well managed restuarant can be hard work and stressful sometimes but also rewarding at the same time.

My favorite character is the woman from safety inspection because just her watching the place if I'm doing squeeky clean work, triggers me to be nervous and thus try to be in top-notch. Also, I love the creamy flowing sound of the beer filling the mug that I can't take it off from my menu list! Rush hour is pretty hectic and challenging but once you get the hang of it, it gets pretty addicting that you feel accomplished when at the end the result is perfect day. The colors are so vibrant and the music is fun and catchy you might want to hear it on and on. Checking every email from the inbox is one of my to do list when I'm playing Cook,Serve,Delicious. It's like I am interacting with real people and I do wish later on there is someway I can type and reply to fans who love my restuarant foods. 

About the update, haven't checked it all but the collaboration with different indie gamers for the new characters was interesting. I wish there is not only local multiplayer but also online co-op version...
then it will be sooo much more exciting to play.

 Keep up the good work!

If you are into cooking or some kind of restuarant management then this game is for you! 
Beware you might just skip or forget to eat food in real life because it is that addicting.

Can't wait for Cook,Serve,Delicious 2!

review: Call me crazy, but I absolutely love this game.  It's definitely a hybrid mix of Cooking Mama and Restaurant Story.  Not only do you get to level up your restaurant and decide its menu, you get to actually make the items through a series of keystrokes.  While it becomes challenging as the speed and recipe complexity increases, the game is intellectually easy, so it makes a great game when you're just trying to kill some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086294752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1421491903}
review:
"Cook, Serve, Delicious" vous met dans l'ambiance d'un fast-food. Concept qui peut s'avérer assez marrant, le jeu s'avère être vite lassant de par sa répétitivité assez forte. La majorité préfèrera donc y jouer une heure ou deux, de temps en temps. Mais il y a tout de même du challenge !

En effet, vous n'êtes pas sans savoir qu'un service est plus ou moins important en fonction des heures. Et bien "Cook, Serve, Delicous" ne l'a pas oublié, et vous pourriez bien avoir quelques difficultés à servir tout le monde parfaitement lors de ces heures de grande affluence. Heureusement, il vous sera possible de vous entraîner à la préparation de ces plats avant de passer au véritable service et de sortir le grand jeu.

Le service c'est bien, la gestion en plus, c'est mieux ! A travers une progression assez importante (via l'évolution du restaurant, l'acquisition de nouveau matériel, ou encore l'évolution de la carte), il vous faudra faire des choix afin de faire une journée qui rapporte et satisfaire toujours plus de clients.

Au final, "Cook, Serve, Delicious" est un jeu très simpliste qui ne provoquera le bonheur ultime que chez quelques joueurs à la recherche continuelle de challenge. Les autres passeront aisément leur chemin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082015922', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 614, 'last_played': 1611705448}
review: First off I only bought this game because of youtuber "Jacksepticeye"  If it was not for him I admit I'd never play this game.  What I found when I bought it was a game with just one flaw like most others I find that otherwise are VERY worth it.  This time the flaw is how long it takes to earn the stars needed to advance often requiring you to work 20, thirty minute days.  Due to this I'm guessing I'm not in the later part of the game where more of the fun is, but still just where I am it's been very fun to make all these dishes and "run" my own little cafe in it.  This is not like those cafe dinner games you prep every dish from ice cream to serving up sushi.  Customers react based on how well you follow the order which changes all the time, however they don't just ask for something random as they do only ask for whatever you have a recipe for which helps a ton mid game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104392527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 3622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3622, 'last_played': 1419393358}
review:
DISCLAIMER: Make sure not to overplay the game.

I have to say that this game is both great and bad. Firstly, I enjoyed it a lot. There was a decent amount of difficulty to it in the beginning but it was also very fun to get into, setting up your menu and everything.

This game has now taken hold as my most-played in terms of time, though I do have to say that it sat up idle for almost 12 hours one day, so technically Just Cause 2 is the most still.

I liked the idea much more than games where you run a person around a restaurant, and I thought its execution was great. The graphics and sounds are well-done. I loved the emails you get along the way. And the food and features were all pretty interesting to try out and use.

The only problem I had with the game was that it just took too long to get to the end, in that having 20 days per star was repetitive. I was fine with the extra events and all of the requirements to beat the game, but the main issue was that I would always finish all of the objectives relatively soon and the "Finish 20 days" objective would always be the last thing I had to do.

From there, it would always be a boring repetitive run from like 10 to 20 days. I would shake up my menu and try some things, but it eventually got boring. Even though I still played the game a ton, I ended up doing it on and off as a timekiller whenever I reached the point where I needed to get to 20 days.

Similarly, I got to the end of the game with everything from the store and Silver/Platinum Stars. Then I carried over into Extreme Difficulty, but I got everything else there relatively quickly. It wasn't super easy, but it was more than manageable. Then I was stuck just finishing off 15,000 customers when I had completed everything else at 10,000 or so. Thus, I had to grind away for that.

The main way I think the game could be improved is simply to add more items to the menu (and increase the rate of food upgrades) and also maybe add a few more improvements to the restaurant.

While the game was still fun, I have to say that it was only fun in the spurts after immediately reaching the next restaurant level and unlocking new things. Still, quite a simple and pleasing game.

review: Que jogo liiiiiiiindo *-* haha, é tipo esses jogos meia boca de browser, só que versão totalmente bem feita. Haha se voce gosta de jogos point and click de passar o tempo, SUUUPER recomento o Cook, Serve, Delicious! Voce é dono de uma lanchonete e tem que preparar os pedidos de seus clientes. É, só isso. Só que tenta servir 4 cliente, cada um com um tipo de pedido, cada pedido com umas 5,6,7 opções de alimentos e combinações, e o tempo correndo, e voce nao podendo errar, e voce serve um e ja vem o outro, e outro. *-* haha suuuper recomendo ele até no preço normal.

review: I didn't know anything about this when I got it in a bundle, but it's a fantastic game. Manage your own restaurant by making the menu and preparing the food for customers. If you've ever played old flash games where you run a lemonade stand, it's very similar. It has a great 'one more turn' feel to it. I'm not sure how much replayability it has once you 'beat' the main game, but there are community challenges and other things to keep you busy as you progress.
