author: {'steamid': '76561197970286203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1388510249}
review:
From the sheer volume of words written about it in the Storefront I was expecting something like an updated Pizza Tycoon but instead it's basically Diner Dash, just with menu-driven QTEs instead of the maze-platforming. I guess "videogame 'journalists'" will get all tl;dr about p.much anything.

How the game actually goes: Press key to take order. Press keys to make order. Press key to serve order. Sometimes you have to take out the trash or wash dishes or flush a toilet, and you do these things by pressing keys. Rinse. Repeat. After a day is over you can buy new dishes (click dish, click purchase), buy new equipment (the only reason you'll do this is to unlock different dishes or automate some of the trash-taking dish-washing toilet-flushing), or add things to make people wait longer before exiting in a huff. You buy new equipment by clicking on it, btw. Oh but wait, that's not all, you can also plan your menus! (by clicking the foods you've bought)

The "menu-planning" is kinda simplistic (some dishes get "old" after two consecutive days, that's really the only thing preventing you from keeping a static min-maxed menu of the Highest Priced Items), and the "upgrades" are only necessary from an achievement-farming / restaurant star rating upgrade perspective, generally you have to serve 200-300 of a dish before you even recoup the initial investment. To put that in perspective, each day you can expect to sell a maximum of about 50 total dishes across all types.

It's a fun distraction and the execution is great for what it is (you can even rebind the QTE keys - major props for that) but on the other hand the "upgrade your restaurant" progression requires twenty game-days and after eight game-days it was getting a little tedious so whatever. If Indie, Casual is your thing then by all means check this out, but this isn't a fu­ckin "Simulation" by any stretch of the imagination and the "Strategy" is simplistic at best.

If it was categorized properly (Indie, Casual) I'd give it a thumbs-up, but the miscategorization/misrepresentation is pretty sleazy. If this is a strategy simulation then TF2 is a wargame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007178895', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1490730075}

review: I'll admit, I had no idea what to first think of this game when I received it as a gift from a friend. A cooking simulator . . .fair enough. But after giving it a try, I'll admit I had more fun playing it than I initially anticipated. It's fast paced enoguh that it isn't too easy but frustrating enough that you want to keep playing to get better. Overall . . .if you want something quirky and off the beaten path, give this a look.

review: I never thought a coocking game could be so addicting. I've wasted several hours in it. It's not a simulator or a strategy game, it's completely action oriented, you make foods and serve beverages doing a series os key combos, something simillar to fighting games like Street Fighter or Mortal Kombat. Don't let the subject or the "facebook look" fool you. It's a great game, and the controls respond perfectly once you get the hang of it (it will make you life easier if you are a fast typist). Get this game, it's a ton of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051530738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1388752552}
review:
俺ゲーとしてネタで買ってみたけれど想像以上に面白い
プレーヤーは料理人となって客のオーダーをキー操作で提供していくだけ
各料理には必要な操作が決まって居て
ステーキならT(スジ切り)6回後にS(シーズニング)の後に焼いて
適切な焼き上がりのタイミングで提供する　といった感じ
お金を貯めると調理器具や新たなメニューを増やすことが出来る
最初は1日のオペレーションが長く感じるが操作が複雑になるにつれてあっという間に終わるようになる
シンプルなゲームだがそれだけにハマるとずぶずぶでオススメ
完全に英語だけれど簡単な文章ばかりなので問題ない

author: {'steamid': '76561198016081301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1496850172}
review:
Similar to Diner Dash but utilizes more on keyboard play, this game deals with running a restaurant and strive to restore to it's former glory. 

Gameplay (9/10)

This is where the game shines most, getting various interesting food orders from customers that can really test your eye, hand and brain coordination to make sure you don't screw it up and get as many perfect points as you can, managing your menu, buying equipments and upgrading your food quality, random events that can influence the number of customers coming to your restaurant, there's definitely a lot of elements that comes into play. Simple, yet fast packed action. 

Graphics (9/10)

Cartoonish graphics is nice here with also nice looking food and it's also nice to see yourself plopping on ingredients onto your own made food ordered by your customers. 

Sound/Music (8/10)

Sound wise it's rather simple, nothing mind blowing here but it gets the job done right here. Music wise it is catchy, nice and during certains parts of the game it gets better. The only problem with this is that it can get repetitive but still it suits the game's atmosphere just fine.

Controls (10/10)

The controls are quite simple, fully utilizing the keyboard functions when preparing your customer's food and the best part is you get to customize and configure the settings to your own liking and corresponds to the keys to certaing ingredients (Example: Cheese - C) 

Overall (9/10)

Fast, simple and interesting game which has a lot more depth than Diner Dash. Try it out if you're interested for a simple game : )

author: {'steamid': '76561197972577353', 'num_games_owned': 1220, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1506202136}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998782039', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1519705221}
review:
Surpringly great game with fairly unique gameplay. With simple yet franctic and fun gameplay and a solid soundtrack on top, the game is more than worth it's price! If the game is too challenging you can pick easier foods or if it's too easy you can pick more challenging foods, though tougher foods tend to give a better profit if you can pull them off (just beware of rush hour!).

The only negative is that the options menu is a bit limited so if you like to tweak a bunch of settings for your game you'll be disapointed. That said it seems to run fine and I haven't encountered a bug yet.

Simple yet addicting gameplay will keep most player entertained for many hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037585126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1396642803}
review:
This game is better than it has any right to be.  

A play if you will.  

Titled Oh!  My fingers!  How they tingle with joyous excitement!

Me:  Hm, this game is $2.50.  I think I wanted to try it out.
Me: It has Steam Cards.  Maybe I can get a few quarters back if I buy it.
Me:  Heh, the emoticons are kind of fun.  I might keep these.
Me:  Guess I'll fire it up and maybe leave it on while I make a sandwich.  But in real life...LIKE THEY SHOULD BE MADE.
Me: I like the art.
Me:  I like the music.
Me: Why am I talking out-loud to myself?
Me:  lol @ the emails.
Me:  **** this is hard.
Me:  Perfect day all chores and food!  **** YOU MOTHERTRUCKERS!
Me:  This is best new game I've played in a few months.
Me:  How much did I pay again?
Me:  The ****?!?

~~~fin~~~

author: {'steamid': '76561197970532145', 'num_games_owned': 763, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 2812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1500, 'last_played': 1503647025}
review:

I know it looks a little strange, but trust me, this game is totally addictive, fun, and challenging. It will put you under extreme pressure, and then, when you succeed anyway, well, it's a pretty rad feeling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024910033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1655, 'last_played': 1528233501}
review:
Bizarrely addictive. It's a basic "perform twitchy functions to prepare food before customers get annoyed" game, with a tiny smidge of restaurant management on the side, but it's got great controls (entirely keyboard functional! you can remap the keys, too!) and really stellar timing overall. Trying to deal with a full restaurant while the health inspector is watching feels like a serious challenge, but it's almost never completely overwhelming. The sound and visual triggers are great, and the tutorial/practice sections are really helpful.

Highly recommended. Other people should be as addicted to this as I am, to make me feel better about spending this much time cooking virtual steaks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998793855', 'num_games_owned': 1203, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 1518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1436178268}
review:
I saw this on the autumn sale and thought that it didn't look that good, but had a low price tag so I gave it a shot. In short, you're a cook running a former five star rated restaurant but due to the last years harsh economy it went bankrupt. This is its second life, second chance and you're the sole employee. Because of that you're supposed to prepare all the food, serve it, do the dishes, throw out the garbage and even flush the toilet (!).

Besides those chores, you'll be participating in the Iron Chef show and you'll do some catering as well and you'll be "dating" some girls - mainly having their favorite dish on the menu and then doing it in time for them and then answering their texts during the rush hours. Nothing overly complicated, but it's good fun.

It is stated that this game is "hardcore", but it's really not. Sure, there is some challenge to it, especially in the later stages, but it's not hardcore what-so-ever. It's more casual if anything, a good time killer. So... if you want a game to fire up when you're waiting for something, then this is the game for you. I recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044130216', 'num_games_owned': 758, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1609884915}

author: {'steamid': '76561198107666399', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1849, 'last_played': 1509937251}
review: This game looked like Cooking Mama, but some reason I enjoyed this game more. It relies on memorization and typing speed. It was fun for the 15 or so hours, just because all the recipes are changing. But once you've upgraded all your food and your restaurant, finished all the side challenges, it becomes an hourly grind for those "serve 1500 of [food type]" achievements and eventually the last achievement of serving 15000 customers. The game does get harder depending on what foods you place on your active menu, but eventually you lose the enjoyment. I've resorted to just serving beer, coffee, and fish (or lobster) just to grind out those hours quickly. I'm glad I bought this from the winter flash sale at a cheap price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071818184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1382052341}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003024671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1600891373}
review:
This one took me completely by surprise. I hadn't even heard of it before it hit a flash sale during the winter sale. Did a little research and thought it looked neat so I took the plunge. Glad I did. It combines Cooking Mama's cooking gameplay with sim management for your restaraunt. It gets fast, hectice, but actually exciting during rush hours and there's quite a bit of depth to be had, despite starting off fairly simple.

It's pretty fun, even though during later stages of the game during rush hours it can be almost as stressful as managing a real restaraunt. In the end though it's satisfying and fun, easy to pick up and play and put down too. I'm normally not too into simulation games OR cooking in general, but this one easily won me over. It has a lot of charm to boot. Great game, highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960449384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1393749581}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972868533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1497043757}
review: It's been years since a time management game really sucked me in, but Cook, Serve, Delicious is addictive as hell. The rapid-fire minigame using a ton of different keyboard keys (you'll play this one entirely with a keyboard other than in the menus between days) makes me think of a slightly less randomness-fueled and more grown-up version of Wario Ware. If you have any interest in time management games at all, this is worth picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020712540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1389370744}
review:
This game is the exact opposite of "hardcore" - in fact, the restaurant management aspects aren't even what I'd call the core gameplay. You get to set up a menu, and, uh, that's it. (You do have to purchase equipment/foods and watch out for interactions, but come on.)

The core gameplay, however, IS interesting - you hve to prepare the foods yourself, so it's a sort of time management/action-y affair where you have to juggle chores and customer patience, decipher requests, pick the right ingredients and so on. It's almost something you'd expect to see on Android, if it wasn't for the heavy emphasis on keyboard shortcuts (which do work very well). Overall, I'd recommend the game - but if you expect a "hardcore restaurant management sim", skip it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036578291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1562895576}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994052111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1388816920}
review: Muscle Memory: The Game. A fun casual sim largely based around memorisation of keyboard controls, instead of a click or phone touch control system you'd expect from a game like this. Under its comfy atmosphere is intense gameplay during the food segments, and strategy in the money and upgrades and progression in the management segments. You really get in the zone while playing and rack up combos of perfect food orders, and you'll quickly be able to do it without looking at the keyboard or the key prompts, just the order description. Hella good. Put on some high BPM music in the background and get in the zone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967410318', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1635621140}
review:
It's like someone took the core concept out of a mass-market casual phone game and made something serious, challenging, and hardcore with it.

I'm familiar with this game's strange roots, a sequel to a knockoff of a Japanese Playstation game called Ore No Ryouri that I remember getting on one of those Playstation Underground Jampack demo discs over a decade ago. Having played that, and "Ore no Ryomi 2", vertigo's previous cooking sim game, this is the tightest evolution of that concept yet.

Each "day" you play in the restaurant is like a performance. This isn't a top-level sim, you're hitting the letter keys on your keyboard or waving the mouse like a madman getting down into the nitty-gritty in preparing these foods and serving them up. In a weird way, it feels similar to playing a song in Rock Band or Guitar Hero: if you pull off a perfect day in Cook, Serve, Delicious!, you feel like a rock star. It scratches the same kind of itch that those games do, with a completely different concept.

It's not exactly the most difficult game, you can get by just fine without getting too serious, but the money you earn is tied to how fast you are with your keyboard, and in that way it can be as brutal and rewarding as you want it to be. It's a ton of fun for a small price. 

Also of note, I cracked a big grin on my face when the Ryan Davis burger popped up in the game, and the achievement that popped up was a sweet little tribute to the dude.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995206474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1494681691}
review:
I've bought this game twice, a first time for me, so that alone speaks volumes.

It's hard to describe just how intense and exciting this game is. It's a restaurant sim, you prepare food and do chores and it's heartpounding. Within an hour you'll be screaming trying to prepare a soup before a guy who wants a pizza gets too impatient, whilst some pancakes and two steaks are cooking and in risk of burning. This game is intense and I love it.

Sugoi 10/10 Would Buy Again

author: {'steamid': '76561198004155199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1459317423}
review: Easy to learn, hard to master, like all the best quick-paced games of its style, the game keeps you addicted with its mix of lite sim elements and quick-paced gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014389496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1457857238}
review:
The Good: Kinda fun. Your hands will dash around the keyboard while you try to balance time and coordination. 

The Bad: You really arent playing it for the animations/graphics but the grim faces of the hobos you serve are a bit of a downer.  There is also a decent chunk of mail to process every game day and the spam filter doesn't unlock for a while.

Final Thoughts: The achievements take a while to get rolling and you really have to commit to a lot of gameplay to get them all. Once you've clicked a mistake on someone's food there isnt a way to take it back! Threw too much pepper on that steak? Too bad. Cook it. Still, Im having fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977458624', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1466530935}
review:
"Cook, Serve Delicious!" is a fun, fast pased arcadey game. The concept might seems simple at first, but like all good arcade style games it gets increasingly more complex and difficult.
The objectives are simple, but fun. You pick your menu and serve the customers as the orders come in.
Each dish is made up of different button press combinations, which might seem tricky at first but gets easier once you've memorized the combinations.
There's good consistendy with the key mappings, so you can easliy remember which key uses what ingreadient.
The key bindings can also be changed, should you prefer sokmething different.
If you're looking for a fun, fast pased game to play when you're bored, this is a good pick.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994679213', 'num_games_owned': 1009, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1388341167}
review: Get's extremely repetitive quickly. It's a fun game but I would not recommend it outside of a sale. There is little to do other than the quicktime events which is basically just a keyboard mashing skill contest. Unfortunately there are no ways to actually customize your restaurant in any ways. This is NOT a restaurant sim. The only upgrades that I found were passive buffs (like needing less time to do dishes, customers waiting longer etc). It's fun for an hour or two but gets boring fast. Still worth a try if it's bought on sale ($2-3)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062778754', 'num_games_owned': 2025, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1479, 'last_played': 1419332309}
review:
I actually love this game.

It has a great art style and is pleasant to look at.

It has what most cooking games have, the repetitive gameplay of doing orders again and again, but that doesn't actually get boring! There's lots of different dishes and upgrades etc, it's really fun overall. 

I'm quite sad to have finished this game in all honesty, I doubt I could find one like this again.

Definitely a 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197979536035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1060, 'last_played': 1438973264}
review:
Precise keyboard button mashing game.
Pretty good for a cheap game and a time passer.
Yet, don't expect it to be fantastic.
It can be a bit challenging before you reach 3 stars,even more if you are trying to make a perfect day, but after that, its a Hell's kitchen.
Some feature might be menial though, like "Food rot", but I think it force you to change your play style a bit, so that it won't be that easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047635356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1161, 'last_played': 1438778162}
review:
I wanted to get this review in before the Flash Sale ends, as it's listed at a very good price right now. I've only played for a couple hours, but this game is fast-paced, fun, and strangely addictive. You strategize your menu, then balance cook, prep, and chores throughout the day. You'll hit two rush hours which will make things pretty chaotic, but they also put a good amount of income in your account if you don't mess up too much during them. 

At first glance, this game looks like a dinky Facebook "sim" that you play for 5 minutes before the novelty wears off. This is actually a pretty engaging sim, very active, and there's a level of depth not present in similar games. It's worth the Flash Sale price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016588752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1697996778}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004549649', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1454197620}
review:
Amazingly fun game!

It's one of those titles that keeps you on the edge of the seat and challenges your reflexes and perception. Much like Papers, Please! this game pressures you in a fun and engaging way.

The trailer and gameplay videos looked daunting, but the helpfull tutorial and practice mode help you become the best chef ever in a matter of minutes! Complex recipies can be easily remembered, and you'll catch yourself juggling the customers around better than a professional circus clown.

Overall, a very good buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198064973442', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1387754257}
review: Customers approach you asking for an entree on your menu in a specific way. You are to take their order, slap it together by pressing the corresponding keys, cook it, put it out on time and serve it. Simple right! Now do it for six people, while having to do maintenance, cleaning and all the other kitchen tasks involved. A small sim after the days work allows you to upgrade your kitchen and equiptment plus change your menu and look at your money. Overall, not a very enchanting game but it has its familiarities to a real kitchen with all the hustle and bustle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004343616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1486494157}
review:
I wasn't sure about "Cook, Serve, Delicious!" when I bought it, and I dare say that even 9 hours ingame, I still have mixed feelings about it. On one hand, I'm obviously having fun if I bothered to keep playing for so long, right? Well, sure, I can't deny that. On the other hand, though, the game really seems to lack the depth and complexity that in my humble opinion, could make it one of my all-time favorites.

...what exactly do I mean by that?
Ugh, well.... The main item on the menu (pun intended :P) is the method of preparing the food. Simply smack a few keys in the right order and within the time limit. In my book, that's worthy of the word "dull", not to mention "boring". While I realize it's one of the main mechanisms of the game which is meant (I suppose?) to make the game require skill, I'm sure there are better ways to implement that. Personally, I would have really preferred a simulation or a startegy based mechanism. For example - improving my cooking skills ingame by means of character progression (taking courses, learning to cook, advancing levels and ranks, hiring more cooks or other specialists, and so on). There's still room for an action-based mechanism, but the current one simply isn't good enough in my humble opinion.

This issue drives me nuts, since other than that, I really *love* this game! The concept is great - just this one major disadvantage. I do recommend this game to anyone who likes simulation games, just be prepared for the action skill requirement. Being an optimist by nature, I really hope the devs will work on a sequel, this time with the emphasis being on simulation and strategy when preparing the food, instead of just action. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049104818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1545447457}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980025682', 'num_games_owned': 582, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1429993651}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious is another super snazzy game with punctuation in the title. I saw Lethalfrag playing it on his stream, so he should get that finder's fee... 

In this game, you play a restauranteur who has to keep the restaurant clean, serve customers, and garner buzz by day, then prepare the menu and upgrade the restaurant at night.

Daytime is frantic, as each chore or dish you do is its own minigame, which follows a unique key combination representing the steps or recipe. If you don't go fast enough or get it perfect, your performance will suffer and your restaurant will lose "buzz", representing more and better customers the next day. Nighttime is a management simulator, where you spend the day's proceeds to upgrade your menu or equipment.

This game is strangely addictive. I'm talking about daytime. The game presents you with the steps each time you have to do a chore, but I did best when I stopped looking at the instructions and just touch typed the combos. It leads to serious flow and sense of accomplishment when you're hot, and serious soul-searching when you mess up.

I don't know the consequences of most of my choices at nighttime. There are unlockables but I don't know how much they help or hurt my cause.

I don't know what the difficulty curve is like or how long the love will last. But it's a great blend of two different genres. Hopefully it is not too much of a grind to get to the upper echelons.

For now it's a meaty thumbs up. Or should I say order up?

author: {'steamid': '76561198001972892', 'num_games_owned': 1519, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1416079765}
review:
This game displays itself at first to be fairly simplistic however it demands focus, accuracy, speed, and good memory skills. This is WarioWare meets Typing of the Dead, and what a marvelous combination that is. Remember your foods, remember the key-bindings, and complete all of your meals quickly and accurately. Sounds easy? It isn't, particularly when you hit the two Rush Hours each day. You have to manage your menus, keep your meals fresh, as well as buying new foods and equipment to make your restaurant bigger and better bringing in a micro-management element also.

[u]Menu Management[/u]
Over the course of the game, you earn more and more money to enable you to upgrade your menu to include bigger and better things. You can buy completely new meals, or you can upgrade meals that you currently own to improve the cost you can sell them for. More often than not, as you upgrade foods for better profits, the meals get harder and harder to actually cook. You can, as you progress through the game, purchase the ability to have a 'Daily Special' which people will order more of, but you need to ensure that the Daily Special is replaced each day or this can have a negative impact on your 'Buzz'. 

Buzz is affected by the food you have on your menu, and any foods that are not considered to be staple restaurant foods (such as salad, coffee, etc.) can cause Menu Rot to happen, leading to negative Buzz. Buzz will influence how many customers you get, how much they tip, so it is very important to get the right balance of food on your menu each day.

[u]Equipment[/u]
Food isn't the only thing that you can spend your money on. Throughout the game you can choose to upgrade, our purchase new equipment for your restaurant to improve productivity and/or profits. Choosing what you want to upgrade, be it your menu or equipment, can be a difficult task when you are first starting out. Upgraded equipment can lead to being able to serve more customers in a day, or reducing the length of time chores take, so they can be of great benefit to you.

[u]Rush Hour[/u]
Trying to keep on top of orders, cooking time, and preparation during the two Rush Hours within the day is very taxing, particularly as your restaurant goes from 1* to 5*. The more orders that are processed without error, you also get a 'Combo Bonus'. If you complete a day without messing up an order and get a Perfect Combo Bonus, you can get a cash bonus that can be used to further upgrade your equipment and/or menu.

[u]Chores[/u]
As if menu management and Rush Hour isn't enough to contend with, throughout your working day you also need to deal with restaurant chores. These include such things as washing dishes, throwing out the trash, setting traps to keep rats away, and cleaning the restroom. If you miss any of your chores this ends any Combo Bonus that you may have at the time, so they are just as important to keep on top of as your food-demanding customers.

[u]Ways To Make Money[/u]
There are other ways of making money for yourself as well as completing each day at the restaurant serving customers such as accepting bets on how high you can get your Combo Bonus, or by completing catering events that unlock as you progress throughout the game. All of these bets/challenges rely on your experience gained from playing the game - know your foods, know your key-bindings, and be able to type correctly under pressure!

If you buy this game through Steam, there are also Steam Challenges that give you a one-off cash bonus for completing them, and also gives you the opportunity to get your name on a leaderboard if you're good at keeping your Combo Bonus high with set foods on the menu.

[u]Restaurant Upgrades[/u]
To upgrade your restaurant from 1* to 5* you need to meet a set amount of criteria to do so - a few examples of this are as follows:
* Complete 20 days working in the restaurant.
* Complete 3 safety inspections.
* Upgrade x number of your foods.
* Complete x number of catering events.
etc. These specifications ultimately mean that you have to be a jack-of-all-trades within the catering industry!

The safety inspections can be particularly stressful to overcome as you have to fulfil your chores quickly, as well as keeping customers happy with no 'bad' orders while the inspector is in your restaurant watching you cook. After playing the game for a while, the inspectors aren't quite as worrying as they once where, as the orders are so fast and frantic at coming in I barely notice now when the inspector is at the restaurant, I'm just furiously mashing my keyboard in an attempt not to mess up my Combo Bonus!

[u]Verdict[/u]
I adore this game, and I would recommend it to anyone that feels they know their way around a keyboard pretty well, as it's still surprising how much of a challenge it is to hit the right keys under pressure! I'm now 11+ hours played, and am only half way through upgrading my 3* restaurant to a 4* restaurant, so very good value for money (£6.99 on Steam) if you're willing to invest the time and effort. Lots of micro-management involvement with the menu/equipment upgrades as well as the actual restaurant cooking/maintenance. Very enjoyable - buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053055355', 'num_games_owned': 1061, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1328, 'last_played': 1545467535}
review: Bought this on Desura last year after watching Northernlion review it on YouTube. Great game, great time playing it, probably my 3rd most played PC game of the last 2 years. Used my key to get it on Steam for the badge and achievements, and it's still the same great game, with a few minor tweaks. It's similar to a Guitar Hero type game, where pulling off combos and excelling feel really good, and one tiny mistake can be a real punch to the gut. I can't really say much more than, simply put, this is a fun and challenging game. And the dev is a really great person who cares about his games and the people playing them. Go buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991679738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1615823304}
review: A pretty amazing small game. So far iv found it to be incredibly fun though it does suffer from a few flaws mostly in controls. The keybindings cant be set to arrow keys so if you want to change it to where you can use those keys for certain jobs so it makes some highly annoying. Some other dishes where you think they should be simple also come down to being far too complex because of the controls such as pizza or pasta while things like lobster and bananas foster are fairly simple to make so it tends to make some things seem odd. On the other game its really easy to get sucked into the game and you can end up working on it for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041127791', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1507466660}
review: Very good game

author: {'steamid': '76561197977690701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1386893209}
review:
Sadly I do not recommend.

Not a bad game, but a bit of a time waster.  It looks like many of the components for an enjoyable Cooking Mama style experience are here, but there is a grind present.  I found I could make $300-400 income per day of play (+250 for perfect days), but foods started costing $1000+ quickly.  It seems like more and more my income came from...gambling?  Some kind of in-email betting game.

Food "rots" after being on your menu for 2 days, but, really?  In this game you can't become "known" for a particular dish I suppose.  All in all, the gameplay mechanics are a little confused.

I've played for about 4 hours now and I am stuck here waiting for my play time to reach 20 in-game days to move on, I'm a little bored.

This is not a true restaurant sim either, from glazing the achievements I can see there's much more to unlock, I just don't want to wait around to get there.  From the get-go, the game is lacking depth.  I didn't feel like I owned a restaurant or anything.

Pro: Some lady with the same sprite showed up almost every day and ordered a beer at 9AM.  Dedication.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091001455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1302, 'last_played': 1489103189}
review: I recommend this game as its very fast paced and there's actually a point to it unlike most restaurant games, you have goals to unlock and a lot of levels it just increases in difficulty as you go along to the point where you feel like your heads going to explode with frustration because you cant complete a level, its very addictive i spend hours on it !

author: {'steamid': '76561198066836630', 'num_games_owned': 930, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1513743124}
review:
This is the only cooking game on steam that I find addictive to play because of it's hard & fast game mechanics to see how much food you can cook, I'm going to post my thoughts on what makes this game delicious (At The End Of Each Day You Might Get Positive Or Negative Buzz depending on how good your culinary skills are).

Pros:

1. Lots of food

2. Lots of upgrades for your food

3. Hard, Fast & Rewarding

4. Good Art

5. Very Addictive

7. Extra Events a.k.a Challenges that can reward you extra cash but some challenges are way harder to do

8. Random E-mails (Some of them are funny)

9. Good Tutorials

10. You Can Date Other People Who Love Cooking (Not Actual People Just In The Game)

11. Good Music

Cons:

1. I thought the lack of multitasking was an issue for me like for example I'm cooking a burger but I notice some of my other food or chores is going to disappear if I don't interact with it so I try to click on the disappearing object while I'm cooking the burger but nothing happens (Well The only Time I'm able to click on a disappearing object while I'm cooking is if the food is ready to serve), I thought there would be multitasking with the food & chores but I guess not...

2. Every time you do a correct dish for the person your dating they always take up most of your time texting which leaves a lot of angry customers because I'm busy using my cellphone instead of making food (Again this is an issue with no multitasking)

Overall This game always makes me hungry & I highly recommend buying this Yummy Game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046004505', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4745, 'last_played': 1502145326}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028253012', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 5357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3678, 'last_played': 1695315963}
review:
A lightning fast game with a restaurant cooking theme. There's a lot of multitasking and frantic action. You'll be flipping burgers, chopping fish, and burning nachos all while the dishes pile up and customers begin to get impatient. You can control the difficulty by what foods you select and how fast the customers arrive. This is one of my all time favorite games and I really think it's a masterpiece.

If the trailer seems interesting to you, you'll probably like the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013595700', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1414, 'last_played': 1439534551}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040705942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1600787803}
review:
No te digo que estemos ante una de esas historias "bigger than life" de salvar al mundo y demás porque esto va de preparar comidas y organizar un poco el chiringo para pasar de antro inmundo a percutir analmente a Chicote con tus tres estrellas Michelín marcadas a fuego en tu orondo miembro viril. Mas o menos.

Y engancha de cojones. Planteatelo así: si flipaste pepinillos ejerciendo de funcionario en "Papers, please", qué no podrás llegar a GOZAR emulando a tus grandes ídolos culinarios como Sergi Arola, Bárbara de Top Chef u Olvido Hormigos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066489540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1435471910}
review:
I am a fan of simulation games, and I have been playing my share of them. This game can be one of the better ones that I have played.

I can come in from both sides of the argument here and say that, this game is basically nothing but memorizing what you need to do, and how to do it. It's nothing more than pressing the correct button at the correct time, so that the correct thing hapens.

...but I have to argue, there's something with how it is presented, something that just lures me to play more and more of this game, it's simple, it's pushing correct buttons at correct timing, but... it is packaged in a way that you won't really get bored while playing it. The rewards are rewarding and somewhat on time. You won't get almost everything in one sitting, you have to gradually adapt, to see, which menus do you like (read: not screw up) the most, which menus needed to be changed daily, which menus do give a positive vibe and thus rack in more customers, etc. It's a nice little sugar on top of the icing to make the game more interactive and press the players to learn newer foods and their preparation.

All in all, for the price the game is worth, it's worth buying, I'd strongly reccomend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074716788', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1465660252}
review: It looks like your typical casual sim games but you'll be pleasantly surprised by the amount of depth CSD offers. You start off with a good bit of money to pick out food and equipment and the selections are nicely varied. Each dish has pros and cons that  can help keep your "buzz" high or cons that can add on extra chores or detract from your buzz. The cool thing about this game is the emails you recieve after each round(day) you play, these emails can contain money, challenges or hints. Another thing I really like about this game is the prep work you do for different foods and the fact you can upgrade the food and the restuarant. The only con is the elevator jazz-y music and the fact that you might be sucked in for a few hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987127197', 'num_games_owned': 1005, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1447016369}
review: Smash together a charming little restruant sim with WarioWare style microgames for preparing/cooking/serving the food and keeping the establishment clean, and you have Cook, Serve Delicious!  It's a ton of fun and the game itself has a fantastic atmosphere, everything looks and sounds great, and there's a real sense of progression as you get deeper and deeper into the game.  Don't be fooled by it's cute looks- though the game starts out relatively easy, CSD! is going to get VERY difficult later on- but never in an unfair way, and always in a manner you can directly control by choosing what foods are on your menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009059908', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2108, 'last_played': 1439170413}
review: This game has been eating my life for the last few days. It's really addictive (I keep saying I'm done after a day, but then something else makes me want to play through another one), silly and lighthearted, and fast and intense when you've got a lot going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116288749', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 8886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1580848975}
review: So there's basically 3 different categories of food games: waitress (Diner Dash), line cook (assembling orders) and management (you run the resturaunt, hire and fire etc). This game is a combination of a line cook and a management game. It's pretty fast pace and it has multiple side challenges. You play as a line cook who also has to keep up with chores while completeing orders. It sounds overwhelming, and at first it is but eventually you adapt to the gameplay. It's smooth, the graphics fit the game right and I literally feel like this is me running a little food shop by myself. Very fun, 4 hours went by damn quick. I highly recommend, especially if you enjoy food games

author: {'steamid': '76561197973048375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1467, 'last_played': 1453597629}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041643755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1436072890}
review:
Hardcore restaurant sim is right! Was Diner Dash a little too calm for you? Do you need to create & wash dishes, flush toilets, throw away garbage AND get rid of vermin as well as serve your food? Every (nervewracking) day you play through this game, you get the opportunity - via your in-game email account - to buy new dishes and upgrades. And you gotta make sure to rotate your menu items out... seriously, they weren't playing when they said HARDCORE RESTAURANT SIM.

It's got jokey graphics and unobtrusive loungey jazz in the background, along with the murmur of satisfied (or pissed) patrons and the clanking of dishes. 

For fans of the HARDCORE RESTAURANT SIMS, this can't come any higher recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056660950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1420973658}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000699768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1393184180}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious is a fast-paced game, where you run your own restaurant. The gameplay is centered around cooking and serving food in segments that consist of one game day, which last for around 7 minutes. Inbetween these days you manage your menu, upgrade your restaurant and buy new, increasingly complex recipes. 
  The game's theme and aesthetics might suggest this to be an easy, casual experience. This is not true. Cooking each meal is a process requiring multiple ingredients to be added in a rapid sequence to keep the customers from waiting too long. Adding ingredients happens by pressing the releated hotkey (fully rebindable). Some of the more complicated foods require specific ingredients to be added either in an order, multiple times, or within a time limit. The game's difficulty comes from this fact, as during the rush hour, which happens twice a day, you'll really be in a hurry to fulfil the many requests by your customers. And if you don't serve them fast enough, the customers will leave with an empty stomach, lowering your hype.
   The hype mechanic adjusts game difficulty based on your skill level - more hype leads to more customers. If you successfully serve customers, more shall arrive next day, making the game more taxing and complicated for the player. This naturally leads to more income, allowing you to advance through upgrades more quickly. And as you gain more hype and even more complicated recipes, even the fastest of keyboard users and multitaskers will find him or herself challenged during a rush hour.
   In between days you'll be able to redesign your menu. Different foods have different perks and disadvantages. For example, pizza will increase your hype during evenings when people come in for a late dinner, but if combined with other greasy foods on the menu, will detract from hype due to health nuts turning up their noses at your fatty-filled menus. Some foods also suffer from "menu decay", which makes them lower hype if left on the menu for too many days in a row. This adds a light strategy element to the game, as you'll be balancing different foods for different occasions and days, trying to find the perfect combinations.
   Cook, Serve, Delicious! also has a few side activities in form of catering for example. These missions require you to cook and serve specific dishes under strict conditions. Completing these activities grant you extra cash, but due to them requiring to own the recipes used during the mission, might end up being a drain instead of a boost for your cash.
   Overall the game offers a surprisingly difficult, yet highly statisfying piece of enterntaiment that can be enjoyed in short bursts of 10-20 minutes. The hype system cleverly balances game difficulty with your skill level, and buying and upgrading recipes makes increases complexity and challenge at a smooth rate. Definitely recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077072053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1499708074}

author: {'steamid': '76561198093890885', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1500265627}
review: Its quiet a fun game with plenty of things to get addicted to! it is one of the better indies out there and is worth your money if you know what your getting which is a button masher with timing and thats all it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989881266', 'num_games_owned': 816, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1386999247}
review:
Love it! It's very engaging and challenging, keeping your fingertips moving at all times. I haven't played a game with a learning curve this smooth in so long, it makes me wonder why more people haven't heard of this game. There are tons of upgrades and different types of food/equipment items to choose from that will effect how your restaurant flourish. Start from the dirt and make your way up to the fabulous 5-star extravaganza. It is a really satisfying type of experience that I can hardly put down myself. Definitely check this one out, even if you think you wouldn't like a cooking/prep game! 

Just to add some sprinkles to the cake; Imagine if Typing of the Dead and Wario Ware had a baby that went on to grow up and marry Cooking Mama, and then both of them had a baby. To follow, that baby grew up and went to a Culinary Arts School where (s)he succeeded better than both his grandparents and parents. That baby is this game in a nutshell.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082000537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1539717672}
review: Really fun for anyone, casual or harcore. Strategy and memorization aspects mesh really well. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003420249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 4271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1907, 'last_played': 1485047001}
review: CSD is far more fun and enthralling than it has any right being. You work to assemble food by using keystrokes, against the clock... which in itself sounds like a pretty banal premise. But by adding menu management, food upgrades and equipment, it gives just enough of a sense of progression that addiction sets in. Just as I've spent many a night playing 4X games saying "just one more turn," this one can easily become "just one more day." Several hours later...

author: {'steamid': '76561198009799931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1387254839}
review: I bought Cook, Serve, Delicious! wanting a kitchen management game, and I certainly got what I asked for! It's got a very nice visual appeal, and the gameplay is very fast. Unfortunately, I myself am not quite so perfect a match for the game. As soon as rush hour hits, I go into a panic and lose my ability to read the orders for a few seconds! But that said, I love the game. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes cooking or kitchen management games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055357228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 10673, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3077, 'last_played': 1709012237}
review: So you start off with about 7.5k in a resturant and try to climb your way up to a 5 star rating from zero. Finding a balance for heavy tipping complex dish with easy to do no brainer meals in a resturant can be incredibly fun and challenging. It can alternate from your fingers automatically knowing where to go to make an order to feeling like all ten digits suddenly became left feet and screwing up badly, this game I can find myself enjoying for hours and I honestly would say the money for the game is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000525147', 'num_games_owned': 2398, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1704227741}
review: Simple brainless fun until you get to the more complicated foods. Great game! I can't wait for CSD2!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030025573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5195, 'last_played': 1527445058}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! is the pinnacle of cooking sims. I honestly cannot begin to explain how utterly addictive the gameplay is.   The buzz system works quite well to ensure that days are never too difficult (okay, the beginning days are pretty difficult to get used to) nor too easy, and the ability to upgrade dishes and create one's own menu allows the player to further scale the game's difficulty. 

The game's visually appealing and filled with little challenges throughout the game to keep things interesting for hours. And while I wish there were options for customization on the restaurant itself, the lack of said options doesn't detract from the overall fun of the game.

EDIT: Cook, Serve, Delicious 2!! is coming out soon. Check out the store page for new details. It looks like it will be addressing all my criticisms of the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089585713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 3901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1484090783}

author: {'steamid': '76561198006615255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1382351959}
review: My first impressions were pretty "bleh" for the game. That said I came back and played again later and found the game simple but enjoyable. In terms of pacing and "realism" it is like Game Dev Tycoon. This does not give you any idea of the real world. But as just a fun time waster? A mobile style game that works well on PC? Yeah.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960320620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1390685692}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious! by Veritgo Games is a frantic simulation of living the day-to-day life of an up-and-coming sole restaurant owner and operator. While the game may appear to be a simple casual game in a sea of other restaurant managing sims predominantly on mobile platforms, Cook, Serve, Delicious! distinguishes itself by being extremely fast-paced as a chain of frantic Warioware-style mini-games. CSD requires plenty of concentration and muscle memory in order for players to adequately serve their customers.  

One point of contention which I rarely see mentioned in reviews for this game is the potentially controversial choice of having players control an alleged murderer and cannibal throughout the course of the game. While not initially revealed, players who take care in reading all of the messages in their email inbox at the beginning of each day are able to piece together the truth to the game's story and find out about all of the people the protagonist has murdered and is trying to dispose of by processing them into delicious delicacies for the enjoyment of the customers of SherriSoda Tower. I feel that is a bit of an odd narrative choice and found it to be a bit unnecessary, but I am happy to report that this revelation did not make the food I was preparing seem any less delicious and did not detract from the enjoyment I had when I finished a hard day's work with a stable of satisfied customers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967082696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1827, 'last_played': 1440527779}
review:
I want to start here: I love this game. The review that follows may sound critical at times but only because this is an "Icarus" game for me, i.e. it fell apart only because it got so close to the sun.

I've heard some people complain that the game is too difficult, but I disagree. The difficulty felt a lot like Guitar Hero. Do you remember how you could barely keep up with songs on easy or medium the first time you played? But after trying a song on hard a few times, suddenly going back to medium felt like a cake walk? CSD is a lot like that. You can barely keep up with the small customer queue and simple orders at first, but you get used it and CSD has a wonderful, smooth difficulty curve. Eventually, you'll find yourself humming along quite nicely with an 8 person queue and all kinds of complex recipes.

I really liked the mini-games that were built into the progression as well. Each of them was a nice change of pace and provided an interesting spin on the core mechanic. I also liked the way the game felt. It is very responsive and I could easily get into a rhythm on the PC version. FWIW, I much prefer the PC version to the iOS version. I was able to get into a satisfying muscle memory groove on PC and that's exactly what a wanted. A challenging game using muscle memory and twitch-based time/efficiency management.

This game is so close to being perfect that I ended up more disappointed than perhaps I should be. I still readily recommend the game but with a caveat. I've put 30 hours into the game, completed the main game progression and all side challenges, purchased every recipe, every ClicknStart project and anything else I could use money for. After completing the game and playing a little beyond that, I have not yet received the 10K customers served achievement and there is still a 15k served achievement after that. However, I have no desire to grind it out. There isn't a point other than completionist satisfaction.

My enjoyment came primarily from completing challenges and those have run out. I think this game could easily be a 10/10 for me with a couple minor additions:

1) A challenge list that requires you to complete a perfect day with certain recipe combinations. The list could be huge as there are many possible combinations. Some would be very simple using the beginner recipes but some would be very challenging if you require 4 and 5 star variants of the difficult items. Perhaps this mode would only unlock after all recipes have been maxxed out for further end-game enjoyment.

2) Expand on the mini-games. Similar to the above suggestion, have the gameshow mini-game force some challenging combinations and building up to harsher and harsher queuing restraints.

3) Leaderboards so you can create your own challenges based on competitive spirit.

The core for all these things is already present in the game, it just needs to be fleshed out a little. The developers did an amazing job of creating a wonderful difficulty curve and establishing a solid play mechanic that's fun and rewarding. If a later patch adds some challenges to overcome, such as my suggestions, I can recommend this game without any hesitation whatsoever. It would be top of the class for the genre. As is, I can only recommend it with the caveat that it is fun for 20-30 hours and then loses its appeal.

Like I said originally though, I loved the game and only criticize it because it comes so close to being truly great. But try it out! It's cheap and even with my caveat, you're still purchasing a game that provides fun a rate of less than a half cent per minute. Hard to beat that!

author: {'steamid': '76561197960434399', 'num_games_owned': 1312, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 163, 'last_played': 1385879201}
review: This is a fun, easy going game. If you're looking for something serious, you're better off looking for something else. If you just want something to take a break and just play for 10 or 15 minutes here and there, it's great for that. Don't get me wrong, you can play this all day, every day... But it would get old pretty quick after a while. It's pretty mundane in the sense that it is, basically, the same thing over and over again. You'll get orders, make them, serve them. But if you just want something to play every now and then, I think it's perfect for that. There's not much else you can really do; you can upgrade your restuarant with adding new items and equipement (Like Fryers, Stoves, etc). Bring in new dishes to the menu and upgrade certain dishes as well. But they are quite limited, however with that said, overall it's a pretty fun game, and if you're interested I would check out some gameplay videos on youtube, it's worth a look and personally, I love just taking a couple minutes here and kick back and have some fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005208836', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1625686272}
review:
7am: "A bottle of you cheapest wine, please!"

I played probably 80+ hours of this on Deura, and then a load more on Steam. Never did beat it again, but got pretty close! It holds up pretty well considering it's age, and has a certain charm that the later games are missing, with the dates and chores and such. But it very much lacks the polish of the later games. Worth it if you liked CSD3 and are curious where it came from.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985215786', 'num_games_owned': 2072, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1381356333}
review:
Alla base della mia più pura passione per i giochi di Vertigo Gaming c’è una netta propensione all’autolesionismo. Non perché i giochi di David Galindo siano stressanti, ma perché è richiesta una concentrazione (e un’abilità) non indifferente per risultare vittoriosi col massimo dei risultati. Dopo The Oil Blue, il buon David ha partorito un annetto fa Cook, Serve, Delicious!, una sorta di puzzle game dattilografico in cui vestiremo i panni di un giovane entrepreneur che dovrà gestire e preparare i piatti di un bar destinato a diventare il ristorante di lusso della prestigiosa SherriSoda Tower.

Sì, avete ragione, ve ne ho parlato in tutte le salse di Cook, Serve, Delicious!: un anno fa con la sua versione PC rilasciata su Desura e qualche mese fa nella sua alternativa Android perfettamente raffinata per poter girare su tablet e smartphone. Perché riprenderlo una terza volta? Semplice, perché il gioco del buon David non solo è approdato su Steam da qualche settimana, ma offre tutta una serie di modifiche rilevanti che trasformano nettamente l’esperienza dalla sua prima incarnazione apparsa su Desura. Per chi non volesse andarsi a riprendere le recensioni prima linkate, sappiate che l’intero fulcro di Cook, Serve, Delicious! si basa sulla preparazione dei piatti richiesti dai clienti (in base al menu che voi creerete) durante un’intera giornata di lavoro, con tanto di incognite semi-giornaliere come gli ispettori sanitari, la rapine, eventuali cambi climatici, oltre alle Rush Hour cariche di adrenalina (le ore di punta in cui sarete sommersi dai clienti).

Per quanto l’offerta sia identica a quella di un anno fa, Vertigo Gaming ha avuto modo di affinare e livellare ulteriormente il grado di sfida in termini di tempistiche. Se prima, infatti, i contenuti venivano sbloccati quasi immediatamente, lasciando al giocatore l’imbarazzo della scelta su come “espandersi” (culinariamente o tecnicamente), adesso le varie caratteristiche di gioco si renderanno disponibili mano a mano, offrendo un più ragionato approccio che – parola di chi se l’è spolpato – inizialmente poteva risultare in una curva di difficoltà immane. Oltre alla scelta del menu con i suoi trenta piatti diversi, ognuno dei quali da preparare con combinazioni di tasti differenti e aggiornabili con nuove ricette (le quali aumentano abbastanza il grado di difficoltà), sarà vostro compito gestire anche il bar/ristorante stesso controllandone diversi aspetti. Un esempio può essere un elemento “marginale” come le mail ricevute di giorno in giorno, che di fatto tanto marginale non è data la mole di informazioni utili che si ottengono giorno per giorno (aggiornamenti delle ricette, dati meteo, premi ottenuti), ma anche la partecipazione a un network di appuntamento per adulti, attraverso il quale potrete darvi appuntamento con persone di ambo i sessi, o la medesima gestione del ristorante (nuove stoviglie, servizio di sorveglianza e bonus per l’attesa dei clienti), del menu e del Buzz.

Il Buzz altro non è che il grado di interesse nei confronti del vostro ristorante in base ai bonus/malus del menu che deciderete di volta in volta (oltre ad alcuni bonus ottenuti giocando). Ogni alimento possiede, infatti, un mix di attributi positivi/negativi che influenzeranno sia la clientela totale che quella dei singoli momenti della giornata. Un esempio semplice: il così detto junk food difficilmente sarà apprezzato nelle ore mattutine, o da gente di un certo livello sociale, al contrario nulla sarà meglio di fritture e schifezze nel caso di brutto tempo, quando la gente vuole solo rilassarsi e rintanarsi al caldo a mangiare tutto quello che di buono e dannoso esiste per la nostra salute. In aggiunta alle precedenti versioni, inoltre, finalmente potremo anche modificare i tasti relativi alle combinazioni per ogni alimento o situazione che affronteremo (non dimentichiamoci le pulizie!). Insomma, David Galindo riconferma quella sua precisione certosina per l’analisi di un sistema e sottosistema riguardante la vita della ristorazione e non solo lo fa in maniera convincente, ma dannatamente divertente, al punto che vi sarà estremamente difficile allontanarvi dallo schermo per la classica sindrome da “una partita e poi smetto”.

Trovate Cook, Serve, Delicious! solo in inglese su Steam a 9 euro (meno di quanto costasse un tempo), con una valanga di achievement e tutte quelle modalità di gioco alternative che spezzano la “monotonia” del lavoro giornaliero, offrendo sfide di cucina o catering vari. In definitiva, si tratta davvero di una droga da non farsi scappare, a patto di avere una buona rapidità di digitazione.

9

Consigliato a: tutte quelle persone che sono in cerca di un puzzle game adrenalinico e terribilmente divertente con un’ambientazione originale e un sistema di gameplay unico. BOMG+Invio!

Sconsigliato a: chi ha problemi di digitazione sulla tastiera, chi chiede panini composti da 8 ingredienti e ne fa togliere 3 perché ha la puzza sotto al naso.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993107872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1428807115}
review:
This is like many other cooking time management games out there (make food, serve it fast - the way the customer wants it). You get the option to acquire new foods and upgrade food items and kitchen equipment. The game aims for a first person look. You don't have an avatar on screen to represent your character, I actually like as opposed to being forced into an avatar in a pink dress. The game originally came out for mobile devices, this is a PC port.

There are two main things I think a person should know before purchasing.

1) The PC game is setup for keyboard. You can mouse click your way through the game, but it isn't set up to make it easy (some items you need to mouse click are on page two for example). Using the keyboard if you press the key the action occurs. The keys you need to press vary for each dish. Generally, they are set up in a hand friendly manner. I think the game could be used to coach typing. To make a tier one salad you may need to press R G O M G. Sometimes sequence matters sometimes it doesn't. As far as I've been able to discern there is no way to trash a dish and start over, so accuracy matter (thus the idea of coaching typing skills). There is a demo available on the developers website, I strongly suggest a try before you buy if this concerns you.

2) The game has lots of dishes you can play with, and each dish will require a different key sequence to prepare. However, there is nothing in the game forcing you to variety. The game encourages variety by having tasks/quests that require certain foods, and if you use the same food day after day those items will create negative appeal. BUT. There is nothing to FORCE you to change it up. At least in the early levels (I haven't completed game at the time of writing), customer satisfaction only affects how much money you bring in, not when/if you will progress. So, a person could use just a handful of easy to make recipes and play through the entire game, with almost every level feeling exactly the same. Much of your money goes to buying new recipes, so if you don't care to purchase new recipes, day 50 may well feel exactly the same as day 5 in the game. My advice here would be to play the game for the enjoyment of playing it, not grind just to finish it.

All in all it is a fine game and is very playable, just not a game with universal appeal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966327239', 'num_games_owned': 4427, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1513796836}
review:
Never have I been a fan of the "Diner Dash" games, but when this game came along it just offers something much more rewarding than those. You still have to manage your customers and give them exactly what you want, but the way you make the meals gives some sense of skill. When dinner rush comes along it's pretty much a frantic mess of making meals and doing chores, and by the time it's over your sweating and glad there is a lull.

My one complaint with the game is the progression seems quite slow, you will be doing the same thing for multiple days just to get to the next tier of restaurant quality. There is a few ways they change this up with inspectors, weather changes or food getting boring (which forces you to try different foods), these are a nice change, but still makes it seem like there is a grind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997277236', 'num_games_owned': 1353, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 804, 'last_played': 1596712226}
review:
Starts off Zen like, then the difficulty ramps up. You get used to soups and lasagnas though. By the time you are 2 star though, expect frustrations. I accepted a challenge that requires me to hit 44 in a row. Normally that's easy enough but I keep failing.

The game doesn't tell you what you done to fail.
If you make a mistake, you can't start from scratch which leads to so much frustration as you can easily accidentally click the wrong key.
You can practise a menu item, but you can't select the receipe to practise. So you aren't great at one recipe out of eight? Tough, you can practise them all randomly.
The game drags out between rush hours, as they are the only challenge in the game.

Despite my whining, it IS a good game. It's easy to learn, difficult to master and actually addictive. Two hours ago I went "yeah just a day or two more".

The achievements to the game aren't really achievements, you get them as you play but they aren't anywhere near as bad as some games where you get an achievement every five minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964694731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2049, 'last_played': 1485438760}
review:
This game is absolutely fantastic, especially when you count in the amount of enjoyment you get for the price. The game has a great, steady difficulty incline, so whenever you feel like you're really getting the hang of all the button combinations you need to perform for every recipe, the recipes get more complicated and make you have to work for it again.

This game does however definitely require you to have good muscle memory and fast fingers once you get to the later parts of the game, because some of the combinations get really complicated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989485065', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1383613903}
review:
This feels like a rhythm game married to a restaurant simulation, and the result is delicious. If you played "Taco Joe" on Flash back in the day, this is that idea taken to the extreme and polished up. For the uninitiated: the game tasks you with keeping a busy kitchen moving by cooking customer's orders correctly, quickly, and while balancing other orders or demands of a restaurant. On top of that, you're also responsible for managing the "buzz" of your restaurant by keeping your menu fresh and balancing complex/expensive dishes with easy/cheap dishes. Complex dishes will bring in more income and potentially more customers, but also give you a greater opportunity to screw up the order.

There is a demo on the developers website if you're curious. It's addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997431280', 'num_games_owned': 1778, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3437, 'last_played': 1415679707}
review:
プレイステーションで昔あった奇抜な良ゲー｢俺の料理」を完全に参考したと思われる。海の向こうのプレイヤーはこれを知っているんだろうか?
調理はオリジナルと違いアナログコントローラでなくキーボードで行うので直感的ではない。(料理ごとにキーコンフィグ可能)
かつて栄えていたビルにテナントとして入り、店を発展させてビルの賑わいを取り戻すというバックストーリーがある。売り上げから店舗のシステムや料理をアンロックできる。その料理ごとに特徴があり雨の日に好まれるものや匂いで朝っぱらからは疎まれるものなどさまざま。メニューは自分で考えなければならない。
怒涛の注文ラッシュを乗り切り、イベントや賭けで臨時収入を手に入れ、店も料理もアップグレードさせていくのは楽しい。
全実績解除済み。
一人で切り盛りする店に食べに来た後、まだ営業中にもかかわらず連絡してくるような恋人候補はお断りだ！

author: {'steamid': '76561197979084213', 'num_games_owned': 4492, 'num_reviews': 1009, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1439750894}
review:
Cook Serve Delicious is a well made game, despite being a bit too casual. Who knew that running a restaurant could actually be challenging. 

This game has lots of content, ranging from all kinds of (upgradeable) food to restaurant upgrades and challenges. It will take hours before you've earned your first star so getting that pretty fifth star might take you a long, long time. Unfortunately, despite all the upgrades and unlockables, the game becomes less interesting about six hours after you first started it. Now, it doesn't become any less challenging, it's just that the fun factor decreases because, well, all you basically do is click on ingredients. It would've been better if you could earn stars faster, or maybe earn money quicker. Either way, it quickly becomes boring.

Last thing I want to say is that the graphics defiinitely fit the game; all the ingredients are nicely detailed and the restaurant upgrades make it look like you're really making progress.

So, in the end CSD is a fun game to play in short sessions. But you'll probably lose interest after an hour or 6-7.

[Rating: 77/100]

author: {'steamid': '76561198082050635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1590240502}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980818970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1115, 'last_played': 1419699324}
review:
I have a real thing for games that involve typing (like Typing of the Dead... and not much else), so this game is basically the game form of crack for me.
It's a great mix of restaurant management sim, and crazy hectic typing game. The game goes through a cycle of start a new day, serve customers, earn money, then at the end of the day you spend that money on new foods and upgrades, ready for the next day. This makes it very hard to put down, always want to move on to the next day.
The difficulty can be overwhelming when you start out, but you quickly learn patterns for the food and feel like a serving machine! The cloud saves mean I can continue my game on the macbook or windows pc, which is good.
A very fun game. Highly recommended.
