author: {'steamid': '76561198010903749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1715, 'last_played': 1688379719}
review:
Cook, Serve, Delicious is not your average restaurant sim. Instead of waiting tables and clearing checks, you’re more of a line cook who owns a small restaurant in a business tower. Your main goal is to achieve what every chef wants, a five star restaurant. Each day, customers order off your customizable menu and you prep and cook their food by hitting the corresponding keys to each item, such as ‘L’ to add lettuce on a burger. This sounds relatively simple but can certainly become challenging when the clock is ticking and customers are getting impatient. 

At the end of each day, you get a report of how you did. How many good/average/bad orders you did, how much you earned in tips and from orders, how many chores (such as washing dishes and taking out the trash) you did etc. This performance can have a negative or positive on what the game calls “daily buzz”. Buzz essentially controls how many customers will visit your restaurant, how patient they are and how much they’ll tip. Obviously, the higher your buzz, the better. Your buzz is affected by the food on your menu, as well as weather, time of day and equipment bought from the store. For example, foods such as fish or french fries are considered too smelly for mornings and will give you negative buzz during morning hours. However, fish is a high priced item and both fish and fries are quick and easy to prepare. For some players, this may outweigh the morning hours negative effects. While following the daily buzz is probably in the player’s best interest in terms of cash flow, you can still certainly ignore it and you would still be able to gradually upgrade your restaurant.

Aside from working in your restaurant, you can also complete challenges to earn some extra cash. Catering events which pit you against the clock to serve as many themed dishes as possible. In Iron Cook, a clever play on the Japanese game show Iron Chef, you must serve wave after wave of orders. The orders get more complex the more waves you complete and if you mess up three orders, you fail the challenge.
Somewhat similarly, in Hunger Festival, a play on Hunger Games, you must complete 20-30 orders but if you mess up even one order, you fail the challenge. While these challenges don’t add too much to the gameplay, they’re still a nice break from a day of service.

As you get further in the game, you start earning silver tickets which you can use to make “silver ticket bets”. The Silver Ticket Robot challenges you to get a certain number of perfect orders in a row with the menu items s/he specifies. This gives your menu a mix-up as well as adding a little challenge to your day.

Although gameplay doesn’t evolve much throughout the game and may become repetitive at times, there is certainly quite a few new recipes and equipment to buy while you improve your restaurant to be worthy of five stars and this can keep you playing for hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021845258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1498961930}
review: I love this game probably way more than should be allowed.  It's a great time management title that is both complex and challenging, but really fun!  You have so much choice right from the start so the game is truly tailored to your preferences.  You also have the ability to map your action keys which is fantastic.  If you enjoy games like Cake Mania, Diner/Hotel Dash, Youda Sushi, etc., this game is the next level.  With its active developer I'm really looking forward to seeing how it continues to grow!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982800962', 'num_games_owned': 2601, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1514498086}

The more money you make you get to buy upgrades for your restruant and food; upgrading adds new features and toppings to the food itself, increasing the challenge of the foods as you level up the restraunt. and has a nice graphic style that fits the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000662689', 'num_games_owned': 1479, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1580181512}
review: I've been following this developer for years.  This game in particular went through several iterations early on, and has now grown into a delightfully polished and frenetic experience.  Things might seem calm as a no-star office building restaurant, but as your fame grows, the pace grows faster and faster; as the sole proprietor of the establishment, you've got quite the job on your hands, and it takes all your wits to keep your customers happy! Combine that with a great sense of humor (don't forget to read your e-mails!), wide variety of recipes (everything from soda to steak to stacked enchiladas), and challenges (watch out, Iron Cook!), and you've got a recipe for one delicious game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1609291238}
review:
This is a time management restaurant sim. What makes it different is the level of depth. Its pretty straightforward as far as the cooking part. Up to 4 people come in and ask for items, and you create it by hitting a selection of keys. IE if someone orders a corn dog, you hit the number displaying that person's request, the dog appears on screen and then you can put ketchup or mustard on it by hitting K or M or both depending on what the person wants. There are complicated items as well, like soups which require many items, chopping and cooking. That part is pretty self explanatory and theres a turorial at the beginning to explain it.

It gets really hectic though, because each person will only wait for a limited amount of time for you to start preparing their order or they go away angry. There is a "rush hour" at certain times of the day where all 4 slots fill up fast and are constantly full. I havent found a way to keep everyone happy yet, and that par of the game can get frustrating as hell.

There is keybindings to put the most used items grouped together, or however you want to do it. Thats a great feature, because the default is most of the items are listed by their first letter, but some are just random (olives are V, bowtie pasta is w) This can get annoying if much requested food's keys are across the keyboard.

The thing that makes this game different is the level of depth of your restaurant management. At the end of every day, a screen pops up where you can buy new equipment and food, check your email, look at your "buzz" (a measure of how well liked your restaurant is). You can also pick the daily menu, upgrade your food , buy things to amuse your customers so they will wait longer and so on. Each food item has boh positive and negative traits like some items are well liked at first, but need to be cycled in and out to keep them "fresh". Some smell good, some are fatty, some are healthy. There are many food items and equipment to choose from, all with different effects. 

The graphics are bright and cartoony, totally fitting for the flavor of the game. The music (especially the intro song!) is peppy and upbeat, also fitting for the style of game.

If you like time management and restaurant sims, this is a great choice to consider. Its hectic at points and can be frustrating, but it is still great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983099093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1471136205}

author: {'steamid': '76561198007659144', 'num_games_owned': 3051, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1587, 'last_played': 1400103384}
review:
This game is extremely addictive! It might look like a very simple game but believe me, it's quite hard. There are some annoyances with re-mapping keybinds (some actions can't be re-mapped at all). My tip is not to be afraid of re-mapping keys if the game gets too hard at a certain point. The music and sounds aren't the best but it's not what made me play for hours and hours on. I can't really tell what keeps me going on playing the game. Perhaps to challenge myself? It's a great casual game for people who still want a little challenge and reaction time training! You will have to work up some awesome reflexes and you might even surprise yourself how fast you can be!

Oh and chores. You will have to do chores. A lot of them. Do them as fast as you can so you won't fall behind in service! The key is to continue to bind keys so that you can do everything faster. Every second counts!

It's a restaurant management game and I have to mention that it's not very forgiving. It keeps you wanting/needing to strive for success and it will take a long time to master this game. You will be able to buy new food and equipment then upgrade them, you have to controll your positive and negative buzz, you'll get more and more customers the more you advance into the game. You can take bets and do different events that requires you to not mess up or you'll fail. You can even date people and stop robberies! But all of that comes with a price! Gaining money in the game is hard and purchases/upgrades are not cheap. There are a LOT of achievements to get, but don't think you'll be able to faceroll through the game to get them. You actually have to work for them. 

Your restaurants rank up (stars) when you've completed a number of requirements. This gives you a new restaurant, more prep stations and unlocks more food, events, upgrades and equipment. 

The graphics are pretty nice, I like the visuals of the game. But as I said, the music isn't much to cheer for, I turned it off after an hour or so.

Want to challenge yourself? Get this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993268907', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1482298252}
review:
Really, really addicting arcade-y restaurant sim. There's upgrading and managing the menu between days to keep an attractive menu--not serving the same foods too often, keeping it decently healthy, and such--but the meat of the game is in trying to prepare foods for up to 8 customers at once before they lose patience and without screwing up any orders. It can be kind of slow to pick up if you're good at this kind of thing, since you're forced to wait for most upgrades to become available, but it gets to be quite an intense and fun game.

This is actually the third game in the series; you can download the second one (which is much the same but without menu management and with somewhat sloppy graphics) at http://www.vertigogaming.net/blog/?portfolio=ore-no-ryomi-1-2 for free to see what it's like.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981750715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1682676813}
review: I saw this game on the new releases & said out loud "that looks like a silly game". Curious I went to the forums, read over a few thread & ended up watching a half hour video from Giant Bomb. I then bought the game. The first thing you'll hear about the game is that it is hard & hectic. At first it did appear to live up to that. After a couple of hours playing I got the hang of it & the challenge started to fade. When I got to a 1 star restaurant, the game decided to come back & destroy my happy little life. Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a very fun, challenging game. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042328642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1477299433}
review:
Around the time the PS2 came out, a demo disc included with Playstation Magazine had a Japanese import game on it.  It was a restaurant simulator, where each dish or chore was its own small minigame/puzzle.  I loved that game and have always remembered it fondly.  Apparently someone else did, too, or else this is a bigger genre than I ever thought.

Gameplay is fast, with enough variety in the foods available that you can challenge yourself just enough to be difficult.  A baked-in mechanic forces you to change up your menu every couple of days, which will keep you from just coasting on your favorite dishes.

Verdict: Nostalgic comfort food, flung out a drive-through window.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962246576', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1397249635}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040923434', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1508313996}
review:
Simply put, it is, in my opinion, one of the most frantic game you can experience - and a keyboard game at that. 
The action is non-stop, though you can carefully take it up, one step at a time, thanks to the games upgrade system and its generosity in allowing you to tailor the experience you want to get out of it.
I strongly advise you do not judge it based on videos or screenshots but give the demo, available on the web, a try : you will know very quickly if this is the game for you.
Vertigogaming's games were long dued on Steam. The Steam version isn't just a quick and dirty port, but features the proper overlay, achievements and cloud support.

I give it 5 pizzas out of 2 baked potatoes.

 If you enjoy it, I advise you check out the equally brilliant The Oil Blue from the same author on Greenlight.
